name: President. –
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on the risk of political abuse of media in the Czech Republic (2017/2696(RSP)).

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, we are here to discuss issues related to media freedom and pluralism in the Czech Republic. I am aware that this week this was the subject of a hearing in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) and a number of concerns were highlighted there: the influence of politicians over media outlets, possible conflicts of interest between media ownership and political responsibilities, and transparency and media ownership. As you know, the competences of the Commission in the field of media freedom and pluralism are limited. They are related specifically to the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. Media freedom and pluralism are indeed fundamental rights enshrined in Article 11 of that Charter. However, the Charter is addressed to Member States only when they are implementing Union law and this means that the Commission can intervene in this field only when there is EU legislation at stake. This does not appear to be the case in the situation we are discussing here today.  All Member States in the European Union have an obligation to ensure that we have independent media, a plurality of voices and the freedom to express those voices, and sadly Europe is not immune from serious problems when it comes to media freedom and pluralism. These remain at risk both online and offline. The Commission is aware of the challenges to media freedom and pluralism in various Member States and I can assure you that we are closely monitoring the situation all over Europe. One of the instruments that is particularly useful to this end is the EU-financed Media Pluralism Monitor (MPM). It aims to identify and highlight risk to media pluralism and over recent years, the European University Institute has performed the test implementation of this instrument in all Member States in an independent manner. The results are publicly available and show that no Member State in the European Union is immune from risk when it comes to media pluralism. Transparency of media ownership is one of the indicators used by the Media Pluralism Monitor to measure the risk to media pluralism, and for this particular indicator we noted that the perceived risk for the Czech Republic is slightly higher than the average.  Let me give you some numbers from the Eurobarometer survey where we are also monitoring the issue. A majority of the respondents do not believe that the national media are free from political or commercial pressure, while just over half of the respondents believe that their national media is providing trustworthy information. Only 37% of the respondents think that the body that oversees audiovisual media in their country is free and independent of pressure. As regards the Czech Republic, the figures are close to this EU average. A majority, 58%, said that the national media do not provide information free from political or commercial pressure. The results of the MPM and the Eurobarometer survey showed that media freedom and pluralism cannot be taken for granted in the EU, and we have to be vigilant here.  As I said, the Commission has only limited competences in this area, but we are definitely aware of current challenges and we are following the situation closely. Ultimately, I think the answer to the current trends and challenges in the media landscapes are more media freedom, more pluralism. These have helped us build up our democratic societies in the analogue age and are ever more necessary today in the digital society. Within the competences that we have in the Commission, we are taking a number of actions to strengthen media freedom and pluralism across the EU. For example, we have proposed to review the Audiovisual Media Service Directive presented in May last year; this requires regulatory authorities in the field of audiovisual media services to be independent, setting down requirements of independence that they have to comply with. The independence of audiovisual regulatory authorities is crucial to ensure correct and unbiased implementation of the Directive so that the Digital Single Market becomes a reality, and that is also key for ensuring media freedom and pluralism.  Furthermore, we are implementing a variety of independent projects financed by you in the European Parliament in the area of media freedom and pluralism. These projects monitor risks to media pluralism in all Member States, as well as threats to and attacks on journalists, which are is unfortunately becoming more and more frequent. They also provide media professionals under threat with practical solutions. And there is no doubt: Europe needs a strong, transparent, competitive, sustainable, free and pluralistic media sector. Citizens need to have the possibility to access good quality news and a diverse range of opinions. Opinions must be free to be expressed, voices must be free to be heard. Journalists must therefore be able to work free from threats and in a safe environment, which also includes freedom from economic pressure. This is the work of all of us, and it should be a shared responsibility of the EU institutions working together, national policymakers, media companies and of course citizens. We need to work towards our common goal, which is to ensure that these fundamental rights of every EU citizen are fully valued and respected.

name: Luděk Niedermayer
text: for the PPE Group. - Madam President, free and pluralistic media are one of the fundamental values ​​of our society today. They are a pillar of democracy and a precondition for fair political competition, but meeting this apparent demand is not easy at all today. The reason for today's negotiations stemmed from the behavior of a few individuals from my country and the failure of others. This is not the fault of the legislators, our citizens are not to blame. It is easy to say that a quarter of a century of young Czech democracy and the rule of law encountered the brutal force with which some top politicians promote their political and economic interests. And it can be added that such conflicts simply bring damage and nothing can be done about it. You could say that, but it would be a huge mistake. Efforts to manipulate the media in our country in the form of, for example, deliberately unilateral information about the refugee crisis by one private television, or arguing a member of the government and the owner of a large newspaper with their editor about publishing cases against their opponents are only Czech variations on similar problems with varying intensity. manifested in various European countries. And that's why it's good that we're talking about them here today. Of course, we will not solve the problem today. A simple solution to a complex problem practically never exists. In my opinion, the cure is by no means new regulations or increasing the powers of the European Union. The combination of a functioning civil society, good laws, clear enforcement and a well-thought-out system for protecting and promoting the independence of journalists can reduce the risk of political abuse of the media. In my opinion, the protection of the independence and quality of public service media plays a major role. And, of course, the exchange of best practice between the Member States of the European Union can improve the domestic environment. Ladies and gentlemen, in the end, let me say that the manipulation and misuse of the media in Europe today includes not only internal threats but also external threats. I am talking here about propaganda and false information purposefully disseminated by some Russian media in the European Union. The French president spoke about this recently after talks with President Putin.It is a threat that we must face together.And finally the last sentence.Let me thank all the journalists who, although facing political pressures, do their job responsibly, independently and with quality.

name: Pavel Poc
text: for the group S & amp; D. - Madam President, I will be less general, because a lot of people have asked me on this point if the media in the Czech Republic are really being politically abused. I think this important question must be answered clearly and categorically. No, in the Czech Republic there is no systematic abuse of the media by the government or other state power through law or media councils. However, one particular politician, and unfortunately also the Deputy Prime Minister, did not resist the temptation to use his empire to strengthen his own power. I would like to cite here the resolution adopted by the Czech Parliament at an extraordinary session of the Chamber of Deputies on May 10, where it states: "Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance Andrej Babiš has repeatedly lied in his public speeches and abused his media to compromise political opponents." are simple facts. The second important question is whether the rule of law is maintained in the Czech Republic. Yes it is. The mentioned Minister of Finance has already been removed on the proposal of the Prime Minister and has been replaced by another Minister from the same party. Prime Minister Bohuslav Sobotka, head of the government, managed the entire crisis entirely within the constitutional order of the Czech Republic, and thanks to his work, the government continues to operate until the regular elections in October this year. In this context, it is very appropriate to say that it was proposed to set up a parliamentary committee of inquiry to investigate the recordings, as a result of which the scandal turned out to be the case by the Czech Police, the State Security Council and the law on conflict of interest adopted by the Czech parliament should have contributed. The third question that remains is whether the risk of endangering democratic competition and freedom of the press in the Czech Republic has been definitively eliminated. And unfortunately I have to answer this question, no. A normal politician of a traditional political party would disappear from politics after such a case like steam over a pot. But in the Czech Republic, a person got into high politics, who has gathered in his hands a huge political, economic and at the same time media power and does not hesitate to use this power of his empire at any time.Combined with extreme ambitions and a clear aversion to democratic institutions, this poses a real risk to threats to democratic competition, democracy and, ultimately, freedom.Unfortunately, even the most advanced democracy does not have enough defenses against savage billionaires and media magnates, because they tend to be very cute at first and sobering up late.However, there is some hope for the future that so many people have not been on the streets and squares since the Velvet Revolution in 1989, as many have come out in May this year to stop Mr Andrej Babiš.

name: Jan Zahradil
text: for the ECR Group. - Madam President, I consider this point in the European Parliament to be superfluous. We have a pluralistic media environment, in the Czech Republic, we have private media, public media. There is competition in the media market, no one has a media monopoly, there is no censorship, no one threatens journalists, we have media legislation and therefore media freedom in the Czech Republic is not endangered in any way. Yes, the chairman of a political movement, a former finance minister, say an oligarch, owns a certain section of the media and, as the owner, influenced the content of those media vis-à-vis political competitors. We already know that today, it came to the surface, it is of course unacceptable, but we can solve it ourselves. We have also already banned direct media ownership of active politicians. And let's say a few things here: there are other media owners who are not active politicians, but they also regulate the content of "their" media. There are politicians who do not own the media, but are very close to some journalists and some media owners, and therefore have privileged treatment in these media. And in addition to honest and objective journalists, there are also journalists who behave more like political activists, and there are certainly journalists who are so-called for sale and therefore write biased, biased and untrue. But this is not just a problem for the Czech Republic, it is a general problem, I think it exists in all countries, and I think there is no reason for only one country to be grilled for it, in this case my country. Rather, I feel that certain accounts are being settled here between the European People's Party and the European Liberal Group. Liberals criticized Hungary, the people did not like it, so they are now returning it to the Czech Republic. We, who are in opposition to Mr Babiš, will soon face him in the elections. That is the only way to solve this matter politically. But neither the Commission nor Parliament will solve it. We think that dirty laundry should be washed at home, and I assure you that we we also wash it at home.

name: Pavel Telička
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I would like to say that I am not quite sure why we are discussing the situation in the Czech media environment here today. I believe the European Parliament should be addressing systemic issues in those Member States that fail to respect fundamental democratic principles and where independent journalism faces institutional obstacles. The Czech Republic is certainly not one of them. It goes without saying that the action of Andrej Babiš, the leader of the party that I represent here in Parliament and who has been referred to, was unacceptable. I have indeed raised the issue with him, publicly denounced his actions and publicly asked him to provide a full account of what exactly happened and what his role in the matter was. I also called on him to facilitate the resolution of the situation by resigning. He is no longer a member of the government. But the Czech Republic has functioning democratic institutions whose capability of dealing with such problems remains unrestrained. We have conflict of interest legislation in place which has prompted Andrej Babiš to place his media and other companies in a trust fund. These institutions are well placed to assess whether that is sufficient, but all of that is just one single case. It might be interesting to know that the latest press freedom index put out by the respected organisation Reporters Without Borders ranks the Czech Republic 23rd out of 180 countries in the world, well above France which ranks 39th, the UK which is 40th, or Italy which is 52nd. The Czech media and Czech journalists are free to do their job properly. I see a much bigger reason for concern which is my country’s ambiguous and rather passive European policies. I do not think this is something we should be debating here either, but I would understand that many of you would like to understand an increasing ambiguity in EU issues in the Czech Republic and other EU countries as well, their passivity and ever-stronger tendency to see the European integration process in purely financial terms. But again, this is an issue common to many countries, not just the Czech Republic. It seems that the Czech politicians, including President Miloš Zeman, have forgotten what brought us into the EU ranks in the first place. I hope that the Czech people will choose truly European leaders in the general election this fall, and especially the presidential elections next January. That will surely bring a welcome break for many, including myself. The Czechs as well as other EU nations need real leaders to actively shape the debate on a number of issues, from Brexit and the future European integration to pressing security and other challenges on which we are often slow and weak. We need decisions on enforcement. I want a Czech debate on these issues as well as a Czech debate on Europe. Instead of discussing the failure of one Czech politician in one single issue, however important it might be, we should focus on working towards a reform of the EU. Time, rather than the EU institutions, will tell whether Europe will develop into a multi-speed bloc, or whether it will further integrate. That will naturally be decided by our own ability to come to agreements on specific problems and challenges, so let us first make clear what these problems are and let us start dealing with them. Czech journalism, as well as the need for a swift independent investigation into the recordings of the former first deputy prime minister, is not one of them.

name: Kateřina Konečná
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, first of all let me ask you today to realize that the criticism you plan to make today should not be directed against the people of the Czech Republic or against our country. The culprit of the whole situation is primarily one person, and that is Andrej Babiš. He founded a new political movement in 2011 and two years later buys one of the most important publishing houses in the country. His motivation was clear. Using purchased media to influence Czech public opinion in an effort to secure the greatest possible political power. We all know that this is not the first time that the independent exercise of the fourth power in a state has been complicated or made impossible by politicians. Unfortunately, the case we are dealing with today is not very unique, and we must admit that we do not know much about how to prevent these situations effectively. I understand that the European Parliament needs to talk about this, but I consider it necessary for us to realize that three important people in European politics knew about this conflict of interest, but looked the other way around. Guy Verhofstadt, who brought this new political movement to the ALDE faction, Commissioner Věra Jourová, who was nominated for the Babiš movement, and Pavel Telička, who led the YES movement candidate for the European Parliament. All these people were very well aware that Andrej Babiš bought the MAFRA media group only after announcing his entry into politics. If they thought that the two steps were unrelated, then they showed an incredible level of political naivety, and I consider their current outrage to be false. Babiš probably followed the rules from the book The Godfather, which gave everyone closest to him the rule that asking about his business is strictly forbidden. Babiš's future in the Czech Republic is now in the hands of our citizens, thanks to the upcoming elections. It is in our hands and I believe that the Czech citizens will solve this problem, and I have sufficient confidence that the Czech Republic itself will deny it without us having to continue to discuss this problem or comment on it in any way in the European Parliament.

name: Judith Sargentini
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - When only a handful of owners own all the media in a country, media diversity diminishes and journalists will become more cautious in their criticism of that owner, especially if such an owner is a high-ranking politician. Who pays decides. Whose bread one eats, his word one speaks. After all, even journalists have to make a living. Precisely to avoid such automatisms, you have laws, rules and agreements. I understand that the Czech Parliament has launched an investigation into the resigned Deputy Prime Minister Babiš and the use of his own media company to influence the media. However, this is not the first time we have turned to the media. Now it is a specific Czech debate in which politicians are catching each other's flies. I have had this debate before, for example in 2009 on Italy. What we have to look for is European legislation that guarantees that we have diverse media and that media is not in the hands of one or two owners. There have been proposals to this end, but the EPP, for example, was never in favor of it. I believe this Parliament should refer this matter to the European Commission again. Where is that directive for plural media so that next time we do not have to have this debate about another country without going one step further? Plural media are the foundation of our democracy. If we see that going to pieces, then we have to offer a systematic solution and not see each other flying off here in the run-up to elections.

name: Rolandas Paksas
text: On behalf of the EFDD Group. - This talk in the European Parliament about the media being used for political purposes in the Czech Republic, and based on just one example, which to me is more like a provocation than an agreement, is a clear confusion over the political processes of the sovereign state and the struggle between local parties. Let’s compare just a few facts. Former Czech Finance Minister Babich is accused of influencing the media and seeking to deal with political opponents with her hands. Today, he is the leader of the fast-growing Czech centrist party and the most popular politician in the Czech Republic. Former Czech Prime Minister Sobotka leads the Social Democrats, whose popularity is declining. It is clear that the United European Globalist Forces cannot accept this situation. And today we are taking part in a performance in which the European Commission, some MEPs, play key roles. The rest are intended to be used as decorations to create an impression of reality. This is not a discussion, it is a new action of a long-running performance. A performance with one goal in the minds of the directors is how to put politicians and political parties that gain public confidence in place. Maybe even more - separate, sovereign states that dare to think and act independently. Hungary, Poland, now the Czech Republic - which one will be next? If we really want to talk about politics and the influence of politics on the media, then perhaps we should remember the cases in Sweden and Germany where the criminal attacks on migrants against the citizens of those countries were sought and disguised for some time. And perhaps not without the influence of politicians on the media? Where is the European Commission's initiative to launch a debate on media freedom and the influence of policies on the Swedish or German media? So for what is this hypocrisy and hypocrisy? We are well aware that many media outlets in many parts of the world have long been dependent on politicians, and from business aspirations.The media is increasingly becoming a policy tool and even a catalyst for certain political processes.So perhaps instead of a play on the risks of using the media for political purposes in the Czech Republic, let us really start a serious discussion about the media service to politics and the problems posed by the influence of politicians on the media.

name: Ingeborg Gräßle (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! Mr Paksas, it is simply not true that what we are discussing today is being done in all Member States. We are dealing with a unique construction that cannot be found in any other EU country - thank God not. I hope that everyone will also fight against such a construction appearing again. We are dealing with the media today, but that's only the tip, the visible tip of the iceberg. I am worried about the Czech Republic, a wonderful country with great people that I admire and respect. It's not about them today. It's not about the Czech Republic. It's about this unique system. Since 2014, the Budgetary Control Committee has been dealing with the conflict of interests of the previous Czech Finance Minister. As a major recipient of EU funds, he should at the same time attest to the proper use of these funds to the EU. The EU could not withstand this conflict of interest - not even the Czech Republic. As has been shown: neither is the finance minister, he is now the former finance minister. It is reprehensible that he has not reacted or reacted only half-heartedly for so long - as, incidentally, the EU Commission, Commissioner Malmström, who is still watching, because perhaps the commissioner responsible also has a conflict of interests. I would have liked to hear from you about that too. According to my calculations, the corporate conglomerate around Mr Babiš has received at least five billion Czech crowns, that is 200 million EUR, from the EU coffers since 2009 - a fine thing if, thanks to EU funds, an already powerful and influential industrialist is even bigger and still bigger becomes more powerful. We know that there was influence so that small and medium-sized companies go empty-handed and yet the big ones - his - get this money again. How about if OLAF and the finally reveal the results of the investigation to the stork's nest to the Czech authorities?The European Commission must act.The conflict of interest, the past and its possible consequences must be dealt with, regardless of whether he was or is finance minister.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: - Madam President, freedom of the press and information combined with freedom of expression are inalienable values ​​of democracies and, therefore, the cornerstone of European treaties. They allow citizens to exercise the right to be informed, to scrutinize and to judge the actions of those who exercise power and influence. The European Court of Human Rights itself has determined the positive obligation of States to guarantee media pluralism. The concentration of media control in the Czech Republic is, therefore, a matter that concerns the European institutions and not only, as defended by oligarch Andrej Babis, an internal subject of the Czech Republic. It is worrying that Babis, as a social media owner, leader of a political party and owner of one of the country's main business agglomerations, tries to influence the journalistic content of the publications he controls. Even if he did not intervene, his power could induce self-censorship by journalists. The concentration of the media and the purchase by opaque economic powers are a phenomenon that has been observed in several Member States, including mine, Portugal. In 2013, this Parliament adopted a resolution on the general framework for media freedom in the European Union, calling for robust standards of control and transparency for media holders. We ask the Commission for measures to support the independence of the media and regulatory agencies, including a minimum legislative framework for all Member States, but little or nothing has been done and, therefore, this debate is entirely relevant. The media cannot be a business like others. Its integrity and public utility are directly related to information diversity and plurality, which need special protection, especially in times when strategies of hybrid war and electoral interference are based on the dissemination of news. false or biased.We must guarantee this special protection for the European Union and for our democracies.

name: Evžen Tošenovský (ECR).
text: - Madam President, the fact that we are debating this special item here in the European Parliament today is a huge mistake by those who put it on the plenary agenda. I would like to point out that I am from the opposition side, so I should rather rejoice over the opponent's problems. However, I am deeply convinced that this problem must be solved by the Czech Republic itself - especially the voters in our country. The abuse and influence of the media in the Czech Republic by former Minister Babiš, who is also the chairman of a political party and until recently was the Minister of Finance, probably occurred and continues to occur. Which is a disgusting and unacceptable fact. Of course, there is a huge problem when the second richest person in the Czech Republic, the Czech oligarch, uses his resources in political competition, primarily on the media scene. The European Parliament is a political body that should not play the role of a wise, top European cadre. Former Minister Babiš is to be torn on the domestic scene by the political opposition and truly independent journalists. The response must be voter billing in the next election. After all, from the position of the European Parliament, we cannot deliver the right democracy on a two-wheeler across Europe. I am deeply convinced that the Czech Republic is a sufficiently developed democratic country that will cope with this dangerous excess on its own. It may take a little longer. But all the more important will be the experience of voters in the future as they experience it today.

name: Jaromír Kohlíček (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, the 1990s are associated with a huge coup in the countries of Central and Eastern Europe. The sale of the media resulted in a dominant position of German and Swiss groups on the media market in virtually all of these countries. This completely unimaginable situation in the western countries of the EU and in the United States is beginning to change for the worse. In the Czech Republic, multimillionaires are gradually buying the media, and since there is no ownership regulation in this area, by the way common in the US and the UK, the risk of directly influencing public opinion by new owners is quite real. This situation does not differ significantly from other states in our area, but the democratic traditions in the Czech Republic cause it to be rightly criticized by the inhabitants. From the point of view of the European Union, however, this is not unusual, and it is surprising that a similar discussion on media freedom in other countries, not only in Central and Eastern Europe, has not taken place for a long time. Apparently these are double standards and that is much to be criticized.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - Madam President, already in the LIBE Committee, this debate has turned into a debate on media freedom and captures the situation precisely: media freedom is guaranteed by law, but it is still under threat. This map of Reporters Without Borders shows the situation in the Czech Republic in comparison with other European countries. But for us politicians, it must first and foremost be about the right of citizens to truthful and independent information. When media freedom is at stake, democracy is at stake. This is true everywhere in the world and also in the Czech Republic. The facts show that in the Czech Republic there is an increased risk in the concentration and non-transparency of media ownership. This is a systemic problem, but it became a political problem when one rich businessman, now an oligarch, entered politics, bought influential media and influenced them to his advantage. That is also the reason why I understand my colleagues that they are concerned and want to alert us to this risk. That is also the reason why we are talking about it here today. Indeed, only citizens in the Czech Republic can change this in the October elections if they do not elect an entrepreneur who, through his own media, manipulates the opinion of voters and influences his own media. At this point, I want to emphasize the importance of public service media, the need to face this situation precisely with their independence and freedom. It must be defended in a national, Czech, but also European context. The message of this debate, therefore, for me is that we need to defend pluralism, independence and, in particular, the strong position of the public service media, which need our support. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162 (8))

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE)
text: a question asked by raising a blue card.- Madam colleague, it is demonstrable that journalists working in the media of Oligarch Babiš are beginning to be afraid and subject to self-censorship.What do you think, dear colleague, is more dangerous, self-censorship or direct censorship?

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: answer the question posed by raising a blue card.- Mr colleague, both are equally dangerous, but the difference is that while censorship is prohibited by law in the Czech Republic, self-censorship is not prohibited.And I think there is a legitimate fear that the media owner is really treating his editorial staff in the newsrooms, and that self-censorship unfortunately works, as it did under communism, which we still remember.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the subject we are discussing in plenary this morning is sensitive because it concerns media freedom. And no doubt every one of us who speaks in the debate today is in favor of media freedom and we are in favor of people who are employed in the media and the media in general having the opportunity to write, speak and publish free opinions. This is not always the case and it is not always because the media owns a specific politician. If we want to talk extensively on the subject of media ownership and ownership structures, then we must say that there is not much difference between whether the media owns a particular policy or whether the media is owned by economic groups that also have their own economic interests and through the media, indirectly or often directly, they press political structures to make decisions, and they do not want to go so far as to, say, discredit specific politicians who are not interested in making the decisions that the economic owners of these media imagine. The situation that has arisen in the Czech Republic is complicated and it is, of course, up to the Czech electorate to decide whether they wish in the future and whether they will decide in the next elections that their government, their parliament will be held by people who own the media and who in some way usurp to decide on the views that these media publish. But such a debate needs a much wider space, and such a debate, Commissioner, must comprehensively address the situation of ownership relations in the media and the influence of the situation in individual countries through the media. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162 (8))

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: a question asked by raising a blue card.- You talked about the problem being wider.It can be said that the problem is not only in the Czech Republic, that for example Brexit and its presentation were influenced by some economic groups, it can be said that this problem is not sufficiently solved in Slovakia, that there was, for example, influencing the local public scene,and can it be said in the context of the whole of the European Union that it needs to be addressed in some way?

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: answer the question posed by raising a blue card.- Mr colleague, you are a very experienced politician and you know very well how this is going in our countries.Yes, it is the economic groups that buy key media and through key media they try to influence events in countries up to important political decisions.On the other hand, I must say that I have been in this House for fourteen years now and I remember the great debate on Berlusconi and the media situation in Italy, and I therefore called on the Commissioner to adopt some European standards that will define precisely,what opportunities in the future will create space for the ownership of media structures.

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski (ECR).
text: - Madam President! It seems to me that in the case of Andrej Babiš we are still dealing with a case of a clear conflict of interest between the political and business functions. However, there are serious doubts as to whether this should be debated in the European Parliament. I must say that I am amazed by the selectivity of my colleagues' attention and the topics of the debates. When the head of France's secret services, a close associate of the French president, commissioned French journalist Gérard Davet to be spied on, did the European Parliament take care of it? Have we ever dealt with the political control of CDF in Germany? When it was recently revealed that the head of one of the great international Swiss-German corporations instructed Polish journalists how to write about the political situation in Poland, did the Commissioner deal with it, or were colleagues interested in it? So let us leave their concerns to the Czechs, and let us deal with the general debate on the freedom of the media in the European Union.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, freedom of the press is a pillar of the rule of law. It is a fundamental right. We enshrined it in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and we did it because a true democracy needs informed citizens who can scrutinize their representatives. Now, without freedom of the press, that is not possible. Unfortunately, in recent times, we have faced frequent and unthinkable overruns to this fundamental right. The so-called fake news gained a worrying dimension and today contaminate a large part of the public space, with far-reaching consequences and motivations often of a geostrategic nature. Today fake news is a virus that contaminates press freedom. Press freedom is also often coerced by the deliberate action of governments. Look at the measures that have been approved by the governments of Erdogan in Turkey, Maduro in Venezuela or Putin in Russia, and of all countries that harass journalists and close newspapers, radio, television and spaces for public debate online. Many journalists pay the price of freedom and some even with their own lives. The concentration of the media in a single person, especially a political agent with ambitions for government, is also a cause for concern, precisely what is happening in the Czech Republic. It seems clear to me that equipping the media for political gain endangers press freedom. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, let us be clear. What is essential here today is to reaffirm that freedom of the press is inscribed in our political DNA, which is the cornerstone of our democracies and the fundamental right of European citizens. And, above all, when it is being threatened, it is our duty to defend it and there are no Babiš in the Czech Republic, Erdogan, Maduro, Putin or fake news that should divert us from this design.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D).
text: - Madam President! Commissioner! We have listened to a long debate among colleagues from the Czech Republic, from all political groups, and I got the impression that, with the possible exception of the PPE, every political party out of the three represented here states: we are able to deal with it inside, at home, in the Czech Republic. And this is good news, in my opinion, because it means realizing the importance of the problem and declaring the ability to solve it. The Commissioner mentioned that the Commission wants to go towards greater freedom, greater pluralism and recommend this direction in the media in the European Union. I would like to add to this the fact that citizens deserve reliable information and the opportunity to get acquainted, in each of the media, with different opinions and points of view. Another, in my opinion very important, thing is the fact that media employees and journalists are people of public trust and a lot should be expected of them. Not only work for them, but also expect. And I am very happy with the view expressed here that the media and journalists should not be treated instrumentally - as in the cases mentioned by Mr Poc or Mr Zahradil - not to be puppets, not to be political activists.

name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner (ECR).
text: - Mr President, the independence of the media is very important in a democratic society.It is humane that many journalists have their own opinions on what they are working on - as do media owners in many countries.Sometimes they forget that the role of the media is to act independently and not as a producer of some ideology.One striking example is the recent past of Finland.In Finland, during a referendum in 1994, the big media houses agreed that EU-critical statements would be avoided.In many countries, wealthy citizens also own the media because they want to influence democratic decision-making not only by their voice but also by the power of their wallets.It is very important that we also have publicly owned actors who remain emphatically neutral.

name: Milan Zver (PPE).
text: - We all know in this Chamber that the media play an extremely important social role.Not just in convincing the public when it comes to elections or anything like that, but they have a lasting socializing role.They are especially important because people can be objectively informed, which is one of the fundamental human rights and freedoms.Of course, certain preconditions must be established for this, and one of the preconditions is that the media system is balanced or not overly asymmetric.And another precondition, of course, is that the media system is plural.However, in certain post-socialist countries, not only in the Czech Republic, but also in other countries, we have certain problems with this.The media space was not shaped as balanced and plural, but as distinctly asymmetrical.This is why certain political groups have an advantage, because the dominant media, the mainstream media, support only one political option.And unfortunately, this is also a problem in Slovenia.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, I begin by congratulating you on the balanced position you have taken on this issue, and I also say that it seems unfair to me that we are analyzing the Czech Republic. The Czech Republic was my model, if you will, I come from an eastern country, from Romania, and I have always appreciated the Czech Republic, how it crossed, how it had the Velvet Revolution. The press and the information also contributed to these things. What would we do if citizens were not informed? I advocate for freedom of the press, but doubled by the veracity of the information, because people will choose depending on what information they receive and I think we need to talk about two levels here. You spoke about this directive, Commissioner, and we need to review the audiovisual service at European level, but it is very important that at the level of each state there is, on the one hand, freedom of the press and, on the other, accountability for the information provided. And I strongly believe that these things will be resolved in the Czech Republic and in other countries if we, the politicians, do our job properly.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: - Madam President! I have an overwhelming impression that in the work of European Union institutions we are dealing with what in our official language, in relation to Georgia, we have called selective justice. We are talking about Hungary, Poland, the Czech Republic, and somehow we are not talking about the fact that France introduces a formal pro-abortion censorship, yes, censorship in relation to the Internet media. We are not talking about the euthanasia excesses in the Netherlands, despite the appeals to really react to it and deal with it. Nor are we talking about journalistic wiretaps in Italy, because probably no one in this room will consider it an expression of media freedom. We are also not talking about hindering children's contact with their parents in their mother tongue in Germany. As for Deputy Prime Minister Babiš, I just want to point out that his deputy is an important commissioner in the European Commission and that she threatened Poland with cutting EU funds if we pursue the wrong policy. And maybe that's what we should deal with.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: - Madam President, the abuse of power by officials of various states is a phenomenon that has its roots in antiquity and, in this sense, I was not surprised that such a phenomenon also occurred in the Czech Republic through the media, as well as I was not surprised by the fact that the European Union, as a matter of course, has intervened in the interior of an independent country and we are now discussing this issue here. What surprises me, however, is the selective treatment of corruption in different countries. I am referring to my country, Greece, where the former Prime Minister, Mr. Antonis Samaras, confessed that he intervened in Justice and ordered and succeeded by the prosecutor to imprison the leader and almost all the elected deputies of the third political force of the country. , of the Golden Dawn party. He also instructed the media not to allow interviews and to express their views. In this sense, I am surprised, I repeat, the fact that the European Union has not shown such sensitivity. Such phenomena must be avoided, because they represent nothing more than mere hypocrisy.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: - Madam President, first of all I would like to say that I did not initiate this debate and that what happened here and what happened at the LIBE committee shows that this debate was completely useless and only embarrassed the Czech Republic. To what the previous speaker said: the Czech Republic has long been one of the countries with the freest press, and I am personally proud of that. When I was in Cuba, in Cuba they showed me the Czech Republic and the legacy of Václav Havel as the one they want to approach. Ladies and gentlemen, this is a selective perception of one of the countries. Last time it was Poland, then Hungary, and now we are throwing the Czech Republic into the same package. But no one here solves that Britain ranks fortyth place in media freedom, France thirty-ninth place, and the United States even forty-first or forty-second place. I think that we really need to see these things in context and not selectively choose one country before the elections.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D).
text: - Madam President, regardless of today's debate, it will be the citizens who will decide on further developments in the Czech Republic. The question is how and how this decision is influenced, whether it is still played within the limits of fair play and whether all players have comparable conditions. The answer cannot be yes, if the possibilities of one of the opponents exceed many times the possibilities of all the others. The risk of political abuse of the media is an accompanying phenomenon of the oligarchization of Czech politics. The dependent media become not a source of control over political power, but rather a cynical tool for consolidating it. The dependence of the media and journalists, whether political or economic, is tearing down one of the pillars on which democracy stands. However, this is not only a problem of the Czech Republic, although it is a problem that is extremely topical here. Promoting the independence, impartiality and quality of public service media is therefore crucial in this situation. However, let us also talk about the integrity and honesty of the journalistic situation, to which the political crisis in the Czech Republic, published recordings and subsequent reactions have set a ruthless mirror. It has shown that there is plenty of complacency, irresponsibility and, yes, corruption and clientelism among journalists as well as among politicians.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). - Madam President, the disrespect for pluralism is due to the fact that various business circles and oligarchs control the media. And this applies to all countries of the European Union. In fact, the troika in Greece, since the beginning of the memorandum, has been systematically trying to control the Greek press and the rest of the media. But if the European Parliament wants to ensure pluralism in the media, it must ensure pluralism here in the European Parliament. On what terms does Europarl TV operate? Although I have made hundreds, if not thousands, of speeches here in the plenary of the European Parliament, and several of them as rapporteurs on issues such as the European Central Bank and the European Ombudsman, this activity of mine has never been broadcast on Europarl TV. In addition, although many journalists come from Greece every month at the expense of the European Parliament and use the European Parliament's premises and studio in Strasbourg, they systematically exclude ECR and me from this promotion. Will there be an intervention on this issue, Madam President?

name: Richard Sulík (ECR).
text: - Madam President, in the age of the Internet, media freedom, especially in Europe, is virtually unlimited. We have facebook, we have youtube, we have the internet, blogs, comments. Rather, I have the impression that the European Union is trying to restrict media freedom, then it is called the fight against fake news. In the European Parliament, tackling media freedom in a Member State is primarily seen as an interference with the sovereignty of that Member State. I don't want to approve of what happened at all. Nor do I think it is right for a political leader to try to influence public opinion through the media, but I find it ridiculous for the European Parliament to address this. Media freedom exists. Everyone can talk and write what they want. Finally, I am convinced that the citizens of the Czech Republic can also take this matter into account in their decision-making and choose the right government. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162 (8))

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: a question asked by raising a blue card.- Mr colleague, I agree with you that it is really very unusual for us to discuss the situation in the media in one country in the European Parliament, but you do not think that at a time when there is a risk that a person who concentrates economic, political power and iswill be the largest customer of European subsidies, will it win the next elections in the Czech Republic in the autumn and will it be the Prime Minister that we should at least know about it and lead a debate?After all, it is about European money.The problem is that this person is the biggest consumer of European money, so the European Parliament should be at least interested in information.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: answer the question posed by raising a blue card.- Sure, I agree.People should know as much as possible, including such things, and let them take this into account when making their decisions.After all, it is happening because the recordings have escaped, it is being talked about, it is being written about, but I still see no reason for the European Parliament to deal specifically with this one thing now.You know how many politicians are involved in various other businesses.In other countries, too, politicians have different media or influence them through some financial groups.This Parliament would do nothing but address the influence on the media.You just have to leave it at that.Member States will deal with this on their own.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: - Madam President, following this debate, I see that there are very serious problems with media freedom in all the countries of Europe.And perhaps it is worth recalling for a moment the lessons learned: if and when the guardian of the European institutions and European core values: the European Commission would have acted in time, e.g.In the case of Hungary - when the government was virtually 100% in control of the media - we might not be here now.After all, if there were an example of the European Union's institutions being strong, we would not have to face our own weaknesses now.

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I thank the Members of this House for this very important debate we have had, about the situation in a particular country but many of you have also underlined how important media freedom and pluralism is in general in Europe. In Europe, of course, it is enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights, but it is under threat and in these times of alternative facts and fake news it is even more important that all of us stay vigilant in Europe, and also in the rest of the world, because this is a fundamental right that European citizens deserve and should enjoy.  As I have said and you well know, the Commission has very limited competences in the area of media freedom and pluralism. But this does not mean that we turn a blind eye to challenges to media freedom and pluralism, we watch it very carefully. We are not planning any new legislation for the moment. We are focusing on implementing different independent projects to monitor risks to media freedom and pluralism, to map violation of media freedom and pluralism, and to help journalists under threat. We are also ensuring the independence of regulators in the proposal to review the Audiovisual Media Service Directive that the Commission aims to contribute to this important goal.  There is no doubt Europe needs a strong, transparent, competitive, free and pluralistic media sector and this is the work of all of us. We need to do our part: the different institutions, national policy makers, media companies, journalists and citizens. It is vital for a democratic and functioning community and that is why we must fight, we must defend them and I count on this House always to look out and always to be vigilant. I thank you for this debate, which has also allowed me to learn a little bit about Czech domestic politics.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: in writing. – I am not especially concerned about press freedom in Czech Republic, as it ranks 23rd on the Reporters without Borders list of media freedom – higher than US, UK and France, for example. However, the concern about the oligarchisation of media is a problem to be followed closely. Therefore, while the internal situation in Member States is mainly covered by the subsidiarity principle, debates about such topics should be justified by real urgencies and should not become regular part of EP business. On the other hand, one has to be concerned about the plummeting quality of the European mainstream media and its trend of concentration. If the main incentive is to catch attention using thrilling, emotional and superficial news, the reliability of media as a provider of substantive, controlled and reliable information is vanishing fast. Such a trend distorts news, makes media channels and outlets dependent on scandals, negative emotions and rumours as their first priority. In the long run, it distorts a sound understanding of the world and exposes media consumers to serious risks by political manipulators. The Brexit campaign in the UK is an ominous example of the politically catastrophic results of the deliberate spreading of false information by the mainstream media.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: in writing. - Shaping public opinion through the media is a great challenge and responsibility. The key to maintaining proper democratic mechanisms is separating the media from political influence so that they are fully independent and reliable. The political crisis in the Czech Republic has exposed many weaknesses in the institutions on which democracy is based. Mr Andrej Babiš's joining the functions of the Minister of Finance and the owner of the Mafra publishing group is a clear conflict of interest, not only from the point of view of ethics, but also the quality of democracy. Therefore, today's debate in the European Parliament sends a good signal that the international community is watching the current situation in the Czech Republic. This is a signal for politicians and Czech voters, which should become a point of reference during the upcoming parliamentary elections in the Czech Republic scheduled for 20 and 21 October this year. There is a suspicion that the events of the last days are part of the low election campaign, possibly also the presidential campaign, before the elections in January 2018. Putting personal interests and private ambitions above the principles of ethics and transparency in the actions of politicians is a warning for voters against entrusting them with state functions. Each state authority is responsible for strengthening the institutions that uphold democratic standards. Failure to comply with these standards causes social discontent, which in the Czech Republic was expressed by citizens during street demonstrations gathering thousands of participants.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Sylvia-Yvonne Kaufmann, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, on a uniform format for visas (COM(2015)0313 – C8—0164/2015 – 2015/0134(COD)) (A8-0028/2016).

name: Sylvia-Yvonne Kaufmann
text: Rapporteur. - Madam President, Commissioner! A uniform visa design has existed in Europe since 1995. Despite the introduction of the electronic Visa Information System, paper documents are still required. Not all visa categories are recorded electronically, and border officials must be able to verify authenticity at any time, even without access to electronic devices. This is ensured by the common security features of the visa stickers, which are the same in all countries participating in the regulation. The existing security concept, however, is more than 20 years old and has only been slightly improved twice. Experts have made it clear that the current security standards are no longer up to date. In short: currently issued visas are no longer forgery-proof enough. High quality fakes have also surfaced in recent years. So there is a security hole here that we are now fixing. In today's vote, we are giving the green light to a new security design for European visa stickers, which the Member States will have to introduce. A group of experts from the European Commission has worked out the technical adjustments over the past few years. New printing processes as well as more and more complex details will make their craft more difficult for forgers in the future. Just one example: Some security features could previously be cut out - in the future this will no longer be possible as they will be anchored in the middle of the brand. The Commission presented its proposal in June 2015. My report on this was approved by the LIBE committee in February 2016 with a large majority. In April of this year we were finally able to reach an agreement in the trialogue negotiations with the Council. I am particularly pleased that we have found a legally secure solution to enable Ireland to participate, even though the country is not part of the Schengen area. Not At the same time, however, I would like to hide the fact that I would have liked a shorter transition period during which the Member States would still be able to use the old visa stickers. Safe: Tendering, production and distribution of the new brands in our embassies and consulates around the world take time. A transition period is undoubtedly necessary. However, the maximum 15 months that have now been decided are quite long, and they are the most we could accept. It is to be hoped that the Member States will not make full use of this transition period and close the security gap as soon as possible by introducing the new visa stickers. Finally, Madam President, I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs of the other groups for the good cooperation, including the Commission, including the Maltese Presidency, because the agreement reached shows that we share general security in Europe want to increase and that's a good move.

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. –Madam President, I would like to start by thanking the rapporteur, Mrs Kaufmann, for the work that she has done, and also the shadow rapporteurs. This has been a long process, but an important one. Ensuring the security of travel and identity documents is a very important factor in combating travel document fraud. It effectively contributes to protecting our borders, ensuring our internal security and also helps us to better manage migration. So I welcome the agreement on the uniform format for visas.  Document fraud is an enabler of all sorts of crime and requires a swift and joint reaction. When the Commission presented this proposal in 2015, it was in order to have a proposal for a new, more secure, visa sticker to counter this kind of crime. It is a matter of priority to improve the design and the security features of the current visa sticker, so as to effectively counter fraudsters’ activities, and this is a part of a wider approach on securing travel documents such as passports and residence permits for third-country nationals, including by the use of biometric data. It has taken almost two years to reach an agreement on this matter and I would like to thank the hard work of the European Parliament here, under the lead of Mrs Kaufmann. The improvement of the visa sticker security is now a long time overdue and we are confident that the Council will proceed with its adoption very soon. The introduction of the new uniform format will contribute to increased EU internal security by preventing new visa forgeries in the coming years.

name: Ангел Джамбазки
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs. - Madam President, as rapporteur for the Committee on Legal Affairs, I would like to thank the colleagues we have worked on on this document. Undoubtedly, in today's uncertain times - times of terror, when the security of citizens is under serious threat, clear, concrete, targeted and consistent measures must be taken. The harmonization of visa format requirements is a step in this direction. The visa sticker has not been changed so far and data from the European Commission show that in the last few years there has been an increase in the number of cases of counterfeiting. Counterfeiters are becoming more and more inventive and constantly evolving technologies give them more and more opportunities. It is our duty to respond and meet this challenge. Europe was the victim of several attacks, European citizens experienced on their backs that someone entered our territory with false documents. The situation continues to deteriorate, so it is clear that policies need to be geared towards achieving concrete results and the situation needs to be improved. Border control is an important priority and harmonization of visa standards in this step is the right direction.

name: Carlos Coelho
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner Nordström, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by congratulating Mrs Kaufmann on her excellent work and I know that this is also the opinion of my colleague Petri Sarvamaa, who was the shadow rapporteur for the EPP. In 1995, when we established a standard visa model, we incorporated a policy initially developed by the States Parties to the Schengen Agreement into the Community sphere. Its standardization was, and remains, essential in a space of free movement. The visa is the authorization that allows you to legally cross an external border and gives its holder the right to remain in our territory. For the Schengen Area, the external border, although legally remaining a national border, is, in practice, a European border. Ensuring their authenticity and security is, therefore, a European policy. It has to be one of our priorities. Schengen requires a set of European policies that are able to guarantee its smooth functioning and ensure mutual trust between its Member States. Schengen is the management of external borders, it is a common asylum policy, it is a visa policy, it is a return policy, it is police cooperation, it is judicial cooperation and it is the Schengen Information System. And it is interesting that the added value of this space has led Ireland, which is not a Schengen State, to want to participate in the adoption of this regulation. This is also a sign of the times, where countries that sometimes make the discourse that it is better to be outside, faced with concrete benefits, prefer to be an integral part and to be inside. The importance of this regulation also tends to be seen in the light of the fight against crime and illegal immigration. In recent years, we have seen an increasing number of visa counterfeits, which jeopardizes the security of our borders. Despite this and being consensual and necessary, the dossier has been dragging on in the legal services, the Commission and the Advice.Thanks to the negotiating team of this house, once again congratulations to Mrs Kaufmann and the support of the Maltese Presidency and also the Commissioner, this regulation was finally able to be approved.I am pleased with this result.Our borders are more secure.

name: Caterina Chinnici
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would like to thank Mrs Kaufmann and all the shadow rapporteurs for the commitment they put into the dossier that is being debated today and which closely affects the safety of our citizens. The uniform visa model applied in the last twenty years has represented a fundamental tool for the realization of one of the main elements of the internal market: the space for free movement of goods and people. However, over this period of time there has been a continuous increase in cases of counterfeiting and fraud in several Member States. This made it necessary to intervene to further improve the security of our citizens, through the introduction of a new visa format, safer and technologically capable of responding to the critical issues that have arisen in the application of previous models. A clear response from the Union to the fight against counterfeiting of documents, made even more necessary following the increase in visa applications also in relation to the increase in migratory flows. Taking action to modify the uniform model with greater security features in order to make the visa sticker safer and prevent it from being falsified will also help to combat illegal immigration, as well as the phenomenon of so-called overstayers, that is, those citizens of countries third parties residing in our territories beyond the limits established by law or visa waiver agreements. We also know that visa falsification is a very sensitive area in which the interests and actions of organized crime have concentrated, which, even in this way, has provided support to terrorist organizations. The uniformity of the model certainly facilitates the task of the Border Guards in identifying false documents more easily. I am convinced, however, that the Union can be even more ambitious in terms of internal security and therefore I am of the opinion that work must continue for a full harmonization of the entire visa system.I thank my colleagues for their work.

name: Ruža Tomašić
text: on behalf of the ECR Club.- Madam President, modern technologies unfortunately make life easier not only for citizens who abide by the law, but also for those who knowingly circumvent it.Organized crime is often a pioneer in embracing the new technologies it uses to stay a step or two ahead of the security community.Visa counterfeiting is a serious problem that must be addressed, and I therefore welcome this proposal, which is a step forward in protecting our borders and developing better police cooperation.However, our cooperation on the visa regime must not only apply to foreign nationals coming to the European Union, but also to our nationals traveling outside Europe.I will remind you that not all member states have a visa-free regime with the United States, and this is a kind of discrimination that we must resolve as soon as possible.There must be no first- and second-class state in the Union.

name: Gérard Deprez
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, my group welcomes the creation of this new common visa model for third-country nationals and congratulates our rapporteur on the quality of her work. Following high-profile cases of falsification of visa stickers from several Member States, the experts considered that the security of the model in its current form was not sufficient and therefore, after analyzing the most common types of fraud, they considered proposed several improvements. Madam rapporteur, we fully support them with you. However, I have a double regret. First, we believe, and continue to believe, that a 15-month transition period is long enough, if not too long. Second, we regret that a legal dispute dragged the file on for months. We are therefore pleased that a solution has finally been found through joint efforts, in particular to keep Ireland in the system. I especially want to take advantage of this discussion to address the Commission on two issues. Commissioner - and I address the Commission as a whole, through you - first of all, I think that the inclusion of national visas in the visa information system would be a good thing also to fight against falsifications in this area and strengthen security in border crossing. Second, don't you think it is high time that there was also a uniform ID card design? It is still astonishing to note that third-country nationals who stay or travel in the Union have a uniform document while citizens of the Union still do not. Currently, the security of identity cards is left to the discretion of Member States. That makes 27 identity documents. And we asks our administrations, our police, our border guards to know 27 different ways of proving identity.This is confusing for the benefit of the Mafias and anyone who wants to use a counterfeit ID card.Commissioner, when will the Commission take a serious initiative in this area?

name: Bodil Valero
text: for the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President! I would like to begin by thanking Sylvia-Yvonne Kaufmann and also the other shadow rapporteurs for their good cooperation. This is not a matter where there have been any major disagreements, but rather it is that we are all very much in agreement. As I said, the current system is 20 years old. In 20 years, a lot has happened. Not least, the technology has evolved and made it much easier to also make counterfeits. This proposal for amendments to the Regulation on the uniform format for visa applications was presented as early as 2015. It was intended to be a technical matter that would be dealt with relatively quickly. Since then, it has also developed into a political issue, not least in the wake of Brexit. Now, two years later, the same problem that underpinned the proposal still remains, namely the counterfeit visa stamps that everyone has already talked about. They have been in circulation in a number of Member States. It is no longer safe, which makes it more difficult to harmonize and implement EU visa policy. As you can see, no substantial changes are being made in relation to the basic regulation itself, but more technical changes in the annex. Nor does it mean any extra costs for us. Our group supports the proposal. Visas must be protected from counterfeiting, and we need to rectify the problem as soon as possible. Otherwise, I think we can stick to the subject and not ask a lot of other questions about visas that the Commissioner was not prepared to answer today.

name: Gerard Batten
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, the existing security features for the visa system for the Schengen area have been deeply compromised. Therefore the updated security features are needed to combat counterfeiting. Hence, the legislation for an improved uniform format for Schengen visas which we are discussing today. The UK is not a member of the Schengen area and is not therefore participating in this legislation. The UK has its own national system for issuing visas and, thankfully, access to the Schengen area does not give access to the UK, at least not officially. It is good that the EU is trying to tighten up on illegal immigration, but since anyone who can make it across the Mediterranean in a boat is going to be admitted anyway, the lines between the legal and illegal immigration are becoming increasingly irrelevant. In fact, people smugglers are now putting only enough petrol in their boats to get them offshore so that the rescue services will automatically bring their human cargoes ashore. It is now not so much a rescue service as a taxi service for the last leg of the illegal migrants’ journey. The big problem for the EU is the Schengen area itself, which is a magnet pulling migrants to Europe. Once a migrant has achieved a foothold in the Schengen area, it opens up the possibility of onward journeys to their desired location. Although the UK is not part of Schengen, our border controls are extremely lax and open to abuse, to say the least. Our immigration system and border controls are in chaos. One simple indicator of this is to look at the official migration figures next to other known figures for migrants. In 2016, the official net migration figure was 273 000. However, the number of National Insurance numbers issued to foreign nationals was 825 000. Clearly something is wrong if there can be such an enormous discrepancy. A leak from the German Government said that another 6 million illegal migrants are waiting to come to Europe this summer. The UK is not affected by this legislation and UKIP MEPs will therefore abstain, but we wish you luck with sorting out your visa system because you are going to need it.

name: Franz Obermayr
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Madam President! The advantages of a forgery-proof uniform visa design are clear. Applicants must submit all relevant data to the country of entry before they start their journey and also confirm their return journey. Ideally, the state should therefore know who is coming. Of course, that creates security that we want and also need. However, in this context, too, the question of how to guarantee this security when entering the country without a visa should not be forgotten. Not everyone starts their journey home after 90 days. What use is a forgery-proof visa system if the visa exemption policy of the Union undermines this system that is just being discussed? This year z. B. Ukraine and Georgia were allowed to join the growing list of countries that do not require a visa. The prospect of such an exemption is promised to the candidate country Kosovo and also to Turkey. The Union's will to expand is criminally ignoring the security concerns, but also the security needs of our fellow citizens. However, I also fear that there will be more administration in the future, that there will be administrative organizations, that this visa issuing office will be organized centrally, that new agents will emerge, new administrative bloat will arise. This is fundamentally to be rejected on our part.

name: Diane James (NI).
text: – Madam President, well an EU-wide visa policy has existed for over 20 years. However, it is no longer secure, creating and enabling numerous threats to citizens across the European Union. The safeguards against counterfeiting and falsification have failed in, and I quote from the report, ‘several Member States’. This indicates that a pan-European Union visa system is not operationally effective and that security standards across the European Union are not 100% reliable. Now given the huge problems of unlawful migration and terrorist threat levels, which even my colleague Mr Batten has mentioned, it is quite clear that a European Union-wide visa should cease with immediate effect and be replaced with bilateral, international visa-exchange systems between individual Member States and trusted, trustworthy international countries. Now tinkering around the edges as this proposal indicates is not the solution. It needs a major, major reset. (The speaker declined to take a blue-card question from Michael Theurer)

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, of course, and I agree that the amendment of Regulation 1683/1995 establishing a uniform visa model was necessary. The rapporteur has justified the proposal and I believe that we should all accept that when malfunctions occur, as in the present case, forged visas, countermeasures must be found.
