name: Președinte. –
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Joëlle Bergeron, on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs, with recommendations to the Commission on the protection of vulnerable adults (2015/2085 (INL)) (A8-0152 / 2017).

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the Commission thanks the Parliament and the rapporteur for her report on the protection of vulnerable adults. Within the European judicial area we must ensure the legal safety of all the citizens, including those who suffer from a disability or an unspecified deficiency due to disease or to age. The Commission has in the past clearly expressed the view that Member States should ratify the Hague Convention on the International Protection of Adults, which came into force on 1 January 2009.  Recently, we have repeatedly consulted Member States on their experience with the application of this Convention or, for those who did not accede to it, on the reasons preventing them from doing so. These consultations showed that a very small number of cases have been registered by the centre authorities appointed under the Convention. It seems that this limited number of cases identified measured against the costs that the operation of the Convention may entail explains to a large extent what is preventing most Member States from ratifying it. However, our last consultation showed that a number of Member States are reflecting on the possibility of acceding to the Convention and several ratifications could still take place this year. In the light of this, we will examine whether an additional proposal in this area would bring added value, and in particular whether a European instrument on cooperation could be useful to facilitate concrete implementation of the Convention and improve the international cooperation in the field. In your 2008 resolution you asked the Commission to present a proposal ‘as soon as sufficient experience on the operation of the Convention has been acquired’. This is not yet the case. I would like also to point out that there is no clause in the Convention allowing EU ratification.  The Commission has granted financial support in the framework of the Civil Justice Programme to initiatives aiming at improving the knowledge of vulnerable persons’ rights, for instance through the Notaries of Europe's portal. The Commission is ready to co-finance other appropriate actions if relevant projects are proposed by interested Member States and stakeholders under the current financial framework. Moreover, as a flanking measure to help both the Member States which are already contracting parties to the Convention and those which are still considering it, the Commission has translated into all EU languages the explanatory report to the 2000 Hague Convention on the International Protection of Adults. Preparations are also ongoing for a joint international conference with the Hague Conference in order to further promote the ratification of the Convention and disseminate best practices. The conference should take place in January 2018 and I hope that it will show the benefits that a coherent legal framework has to offer in this field.  I am looking forward to the participation of the rapporteur and other interested Members of this Parliament in this event. In my opinion, vulnerable adults should also be able to benefit from the currently ongoing digital progress: they should not be left behind by the younger and more dynamic members of the society. This concerns not only those incapable of being masters of their affairs, but also those left aside by the digital revolution, those vulnerable in the face of technological changes. These changes are rapid and can have a lot of benefits for everybody. I am glad that the Parliament is concerned about the fate of all citizens.

name: Joëlle Bergeron
text: rapporteur. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am particularly pleased to present to you today my own-initiative report on the protection of so-called vulnerable adults. In accordance with Rule 46 of the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament, it contains recommendations made to the Commission. This is a topic that particularly interested me, as it deals with the problems and difficulties that European citizens may encounter or that they encounter in the implementation of their rights. We need to be aware that each of us may one day be directly or indirectly affected by vulnerability. Vulnerability can have physical or psychological origins. It can be the consequence of an accident of life or be due to degenerative diseases associated with old age. I firmly believe that, given the difficulties currently facing the European Union and its institutions, it is essential for the Union to come closer to its fellow citizens and deal with matters which concern them directly. Protecting the most disadvantaged among us strikes me as an essential mission. In the Committee on Legal Affairs, we agreed to define the notion of vulnerable adults as being natural persons having reached the age of 18 who are, temporarily or permanently, in a situation of incapacity to manage their person and / or their heritage. This is the definition which takes up that of the Hague Convention of January 13, 2000. Each Member State of the Union has its own legal framework with different standards for the protection of vulnerable adults. However, the free movement of people leads to the creation of cross-border legal ties such as, for example, having a place of residence or assets abroad, working abroad, marrying a foreigner or abroad, to found a family or to divorce in a State of the Union other than that of his nationality or, simply, to retire in another State of the Union. The wealth of vulnerable people can be spread over several Member States, without there being a uniform legal framework within the Union to protect their rights. Disparity in national laws too often delays decision-making regarding the private and personal lives, or health, of vulnerable adults. This in fact creates obstacles to the exercise of their freedom of movement and makes the protection of their person and their heritage impossible. Filling this legal vacuum would allow these people to fully benefit from the principle of free movement and residence, which is one of the fundamental principles of our European law. The objective is not to harmonize the existing protection measures in each Member State, the establishment of which is the sole responsibility of the States, but to put in place a set of legal rules aimed at facilitating information, the recognition and enforcement of decisions concerning vulnerable adults in cross-border situations and to strengthen cooperation between Member States in this area. The main objectives of this proposal for a recommendation are as follows: to promote the automatic recognition and enforcement of protective measures taken by the authorities of a Member State in other Member States without the need for recourse to a judgment of exequatur. These are procedures that are long, expensive and uncertain; implement national files or registers listing, on the one hand, administrative and judicial decisions concerning protection measures and, on the other hand, where they exist, incapacity mandates; put in place single Union forms intended to facilitate information concerning administrative decisions and judicial proceedings relating to vulnerable adults; ensure that the sharing between Member States of information relating to the protection status of vulnerable adults takes place in compliance with the principle of confidentiality and the rules relating to the protection of personal data. In conclusion, I would remind you that currently, in international law, the reference legal instrument for intra and extra-community cross-border disputes concerning vulnerable adults is the Hague Convention of January 13, 2000. It entered into force on January 1, 2009 To date, around fifteen states have signed it and only seven have ratified it in 8 years, namely Germany, Austria, Estonia, United Kingdom, but only for Scotland, Finland, the Czech Republic and France. This is clearly insufficient to ensure its application. We hope that the Commission will follow our recommendations. This would greatly facilitate the lives of vulnerable adults affected by cross-border situations. This would make life easier for those around them as well as that of professionals who are in contact with these situations. Thanks for them.

name: Victor Negrescu
text: on behalf of the S & D group. - Mr President, people who are vulnerable due to age-related illnesses or disabilities, moving to or living in other European countries, will be able to enjoy more rights and more protection if Member States implement the recommendations in this report. adopted in the plenary of the European Parliament. I am glad that I contributed as a Member of the European Parliament and shadow rapporteur of the Social Democratic Group to the construction of this document. It is an important step forward in protecting vulnerable citizens who are traveling to Europe. Unfortunately today, a senior who wants to go to another country may face the danger of not being granted some rights, and the higher the risk, the more vulnerable he is. The project thus seeks to partially solve this problem and to guarantee the legal protection of persons and property through cooperation between Member States. First of all, it is a gesture of humanity. When you are suffering from old age or are affected by a disability, you deserve your rights to be fully protected, including when you move from one country to another and not be harassed by the authorities or blocked by excessive bureaucracy. . My and my political group's amendments referred to increasing the number of vulnerable people included, especially given the large number of European citizens living outside their country of origin today, including, of course, many vulnerable people. All citizens, without discrimination, must enjoy freedom of movement in the European Union, which is why tools need to be developed at European level to address the difficulties of moving or living in other European countries for vulnerable adults, who need to be able to do so. protection is guaranteed. In this regard, the request It is for the European Parliament to guarantee the movement, recognition and enforcement by the authorities of the Member States of the protection measures taken in favor of a vulnerable adult by the authorities of another State.But our central goal remains to clearly encourage Member States to sign and ratify the Hague Convention on International Protection of Adults, but also to stimulate improved cooperation between Member States, automatic recognition and enforcement of decisions on the protection of vulnerable adults.

name: Νότης Μαριάς
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr President, in the modern world we are seeing intense mobility. At the same time, due to European citizenship, adults and especially the elderly travel or even settle as retirees in other member countries. In the European Union there is an aging population with 37% of the population being over 60 years old, while 10% of the population is over 80 years old. Seniors are usually vulnerable to illness and other problems which, if you will, raise questions about how they should manage, if they can manage, their own property or even their personal affairs. This is especially true with Alzheimer's disease and other problems that exist. We therefore consider intervention to be important in order to have a single legal framework for vulnerable adults, and I think that the initiative taken by the European Parliament is important.

name: António Marinho e Pinto
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, this report by Mrs Joëlle Bergeron challenges us on one of the fundamental dimensions of solidarity, namely, that of guaranteeing all citizens the conditions for a dignified end of life. It is on this point of solidarity that I want to discuss now. Solidarity is today a political imperative of modern rule of law, perhaps its most impressive social brand. It does not stem from a religious impulse, from fear or from the love of a deity on the part of other human beings, but is rather an emanation of human dignity that imposes itself as a political demand on society as a whole, that is, on the State itself. Solidarity as an ethical-political imperative is an achievement of illustration, it is one of the most emblematic syntheses of the values ​​of the European Renaissance and the Enlightenment. Unfortunately, all over the world, we are witnessing its political devaluation, now referring to private institutions the obligations that it imposes on States, now, quite simply, ignoring these obligations. It is therefore necessary, I would say even imperative, to reinforce the political content of solidarity, with normative measures that make it effective in the lives of the most vulnerable citizens of the European Union, especially the elderly. There is therefore a need for political decisions that guarantee these fellow citizens the full exercise of one of the Union's Fundamental Rights: the right of movement. Only then will another value of Europe's Charter of Fundamental Rights be valued: citizenship. For all this, and adapting a well-known phrase, I say that this report asks Parliament and the Commission to take this small political-normative step, which, however, will be a giant step in the lives of millions of our compatriots.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, people suffering from mental or other illnesses, which prevent them from managing their property or even themselves, need special care, both from the Member States and from the European Union. The Union must demonstrate its social character by providing more funding for the protection of vulnerable people, especially in Member States facing economic problems and waves of migration. In practice, however, not only is this not the case, but the harsh economic austerity measures imposed in Greece and other Member States have had an unprecedented negative impact on health and insurance coverage systems. These policies have made life difficult for millions of vulnerable people, especially the elderly, people with disabilities, refugees, and people with serious physical or mental illnesses. All of them are impoverished and deprived of adequate social protection and decent living conditions. In fact, they are often led to premature death, while their dignity is eroded daily. The report, which I hope will be adopted by a large majority in the European Parliament today, contains a number of targeted recommendations to the European Commission on the protection of vulnerable people. I call on the Commission to respond swiftly and fully to these recommendations.

name: Gilles Lebreton
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, the European population is aging and there are therefore more and more vulnerable adults. It is therefore legitimate to be concerned. Sadly, the Bergeron report misses the mark. The European Parliament should have identified the legal solutions already implemented by certain Member States of the Union and confined itself to recommending that other States take inspiration from them. This would have made it possible to pay tribute to France, which has put in place for just ten years an effective system of mandate for future protection. The Bergeron report preferred to sacrifice to the federalist cult of standardization. Instead of respecting the freedom of each State, he deplores the fact that differences exist between national laws, without wishing to understand that this legal diversity is a cultural richness. And he proposes to the Commission to draw up a regulation which will impose a standardized straitjacket, like the European form of incapacity mandate which he is asking for. In the name of the principle of subsidiarity and, more deeply, out of respect for national sovereignty, I will therefore oppose this report.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI).
text: - Mr President, the number of our fellow citizens who fall into the category of vulnerable adults, whether elderly or disabled, is high and it is to everyone's honor that we have a resolution on protection and rights here today. of these fellow human beings. After all, the quality and level of a society is judged by the way it supports its weakest members. Unfortunately, however, the situation is far from ideal in many countries of the Union. In Greece, in order for an adult parent with mental disability to take on the legal support of his or her child, he or she must go through an entire legal process, which in fact costs him a respectable amount. However, it is a great hypocrisy of the Union on the one hand to vote on reports aimed at improving the quality of life of these people and, on the other hand, not to exclude their parents from cuts in salaries, pensions and allowances. On the contrary, through the prerequisites imposed by the Union itself, it impoverishes their lives. Expenses for a family with a disabled member are increased. I therefore call on the European Parliament and the Commission to ensure that these individuals and their parents are excluded from the cuts in salaries, pensions and allowances, which the government in Greece misleads calls "reforms".

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE).
text: - Mr President, we are dealing here with the protection of vulnerable adults, that is, all those of legal age, over eighteen years of age who, temporarily or permanently, cannot manage themselves due to disability or cannot manage their assets. There is no doubt that the Member States, in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity, already have their own normative compendium, their own rules, their legal framework to guarantee this protection. But there is a legal vacuum - and that is why we are here debating this issue today - when a vulnerable adult goes from one State to another, moves from one Member State to another or has assets spread over different Member States. There is a legal vacuum to guarantee the freedom of movement of this vulnerable adult and also to guarantee her assets. We therefore propose to use, create a European mechanism that can protect these people with disabilities, these people with difficulties, these vulnerable adults, so that they can circulate and so that the protection that a Member State has provided to that person, to that vulnerable adult can be recognized and executed in another Member State, so that recognition can be guaranteed. We also propose to strengthen coordination, cooperation and communication between Member States so that this protection can be guaranteed. There is a need, therefore, to protect and fill that gap, even if there is only one vulnerable person. The European Parliament and all the European institutions do not create rights, but they do have to guarantee them, and that is why it is necessary to guarantee that not a single vulnerable person is left without the protection of their rights. There is no doubt that the "flag" instrument of private international law is the Hague Convention, but it has only been signed by nine Member States and ratified by seven. The United Nations Convention on Human Rights must also serve us of People with Disabilities.In short, I have seen that there is very good will on the part of the commissioner.I ask you, Commissioner, that all legal gaps be filled to guarantee the rights of all people, and especially vulnerable adults.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, our debate today touches the hearts, the very lives of people, elderly people who are no longer able to manage themselves and their assets, who move from one country to another in Europe, relatives , siblings, perhaps parents who have already joined their children abroad for many years, people who want to return to their country of origin after years of emigration. Europe is also this. But while free movement works, sometimes it's the bureaucracy that makes relocation complicated. The life of vulnerable adults, the rules governing the ability to be guardians, to manage their assets, are the exclusive competence of the Member States. And it is understandable, but what we are saying today is asking for greater flexibility, greater simplification for the recognition of these protections among member countries, so that we do not have to start everything from scratch, single forms of unsuitability protection, greater cooperation for greater protection, so that vulnerability is not an obstacle, even in the face of administrations.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, that an adult person with some kind of disability or illness can move freely should be guaranteed in the European Union. Likewise, that a legal representative of said person can receive a certificate from the authorities of his country in a reasonable period of time would also be a consolidated right. These are just a few examples of what we intend to approve here today. We want the European Commission, through a simple regulation, to force member states to fulfill their international commitments on cross-border cooperation for vulnerable people of legal age. Mrs Jourová, I think that you should not oppose this proposal that we are sending to the Commission from Parliament. Unfortunately, as a coordinator in the Committee on Petitions, I have heard countless times that the European Commission does not have competence in these matters. However, under the principle of subsidiarity - it is Article 5, paragraph 3, of the Treaty on European Union - when States do not fulfill their obligations, the European Commission must take action on the matter. So I ask you not to throw balls out for once and to guarantee non-discrimination and free movement of these people.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I will be voting in favor of this report because it is a balanced text on an important issue for the rights of vulnerable adults, and I thank the rapporteur for it. The report does not address artificial problems, but rather problems that already exist in reality and cause real problems for real citizens of the European Union. More and more citizens of the Member States are enjoying freedom of movement within the European Union. One million three hundred thousand citizens over the age of 65 do not live in their original Member State. And especially senior citizens can benefit from the implementation of the proposals contained in this report. Although the rules for dealing with situations with a cross-border element are regulated by a number of European or international regulations, this is a very diverse area regulated by various types of legislation. Today, citizens expect legislation to reflect its increased mobility. Today, citizens also rightly expect that if they can legally move across borders and legally acquire property in different Member States, they will also be able, for example, to authorize their relatives residing in another Member State to manage it without unnecessary administrative procedures. I believe that the proposed harmonization of the recognition of the enforcement of decisions taken by the authorities of the Member States in the current existence of a clearly defined public policy reservation is in the interests of the citizens of the European Union. Above all, the future regulation must be as clear as possible and must create a clear and simple system that is understandable to the average citizen. If we close the gap in the law, we must first and foremost keep in mind the creation of functional rules that adequately respond to the existing situation.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D).
text: - Mr Chairman!Commissioner!Let me start by congratulating and commending the rapporteur, Bergeron, and also the shadow rapporteur, Mr Nebrescu, for the way they have prepared this report.We know who we are talking about, we have recommendations for actions and a specific schedule.A lot of arguments have already been made and there is no point in repeating them, but I would like to mention the essential point: we are talking about citizens of the European Union.If we want the Union not to be a union of states, governments and coalitions, but a union of citizens, this is precisely what this sensitivity is about.Yes, this is the Union of Citizens.I believe that, in the context of the Union of citizens, we should not only talk about those who are healthy, young and rich, but also - to the same extent - about those who are in need.In this respect, the goal has been achieved here.Congratulations once again to the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteur.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the protection of vulnerable people is an issue that deserves a lot of attention. These are adults who find themselves temporarily or permanently unable to be self-sufficient, whose protection needs increasing attention. It is now generally recognized that the weak subject must be considered the holder of special legal positions that must be coordinated in the framework of interpersonal and international relations. Many EU countries have ratified the 2000 Hague Convention on the protection of vulnerable adults, but it is necessary for all Member States to ratify it in order to make the protection of these individuals homogeneous in all EU countries. Unfortunately, the EU countries each have specific legislation and there is not always legal uniformity between Member States, obviously creating significant legal difficulties for vulnerable adults. It is therefore necessary for Europe to work to identify best practices so that the Hague Convention is fully implemented and that the problems and delays recorded up to now are overcome.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Mr. President, adults who are temporarily or permanently unable to take care of themselves are one of the most vulnerable groups to whom every mature society feels a special obligation.Often in this home we talk about the positive rights of various social groups made up of healthy adults, able to work and function unhindered in society.I am glad that today we are also discussing those for whom our solidarity is a basic precondition for a normal life.Protecting vulnerable adults in the exercise of their freedoms of movement is a particular challenge due to the still present fragmentation of judicial systems in Europe.Encouraging the full recognition of protection measures adopted by the competent authorities of one Member State in all other Member States and sharing information on the status of protection are key recommendations of this report, which I can only welcome.By fully implementing them, a vulnerable adult will enjoy a higher level of legal certainty and is therefore a step in the right direction.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, of course, I agree with the report and I congratulate my colleagues who have worked. Vulnerable adults must be protected. All people who have problems must be protected. You said that it was difficult to have the Hague Convention ratified, but at the same time you said that you could intervene with the European instrument of cooperation, which could help Member States in ratifying the Hague Convention. People's lives must be protected and vulnerable people unfortunately do not enjoy protection in many countries. In poorer countries, funding is needed, there are not enough funds. I also believe that vulnerable people should enjoy mobility and how can this mobility exist if they do not have money, if they cannot move? Vulnerable people are often used and their situation is taken advantage of. I am a humanist and I believe that we must show solidarity and I am part of the Social Democratic Group here in the European Parliament, I am in a humanist party in my country and I believe that nothing is more important than finding concrete solutions so that these vulnerable people, adults, to be protected and to enjoy life as long as they have it.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I can repeat what I said at the beginning, namely that the Commission is fully committed to the international protection of adults and will keep Parliament informed on any developments in the field.  There were many questions regarding the ratification of the Hague Convention, so let me just briefly inform you about where we are on this. We have been consulting with the Member States on a continuous basis, but we did a screening at the end of 2016 and the findings were that nine Member States have ratified and acceded to the Convention; seven have signed; Portugal, Latvia and Ireland are about to ratify the Convention before the end of 2017; Slovakia is about to start preparation for the international procedure for signature and ratification; and Belgium has recently signed the Convention and will soon begin the ratification process. In Italy the bill prepared by the Government for the ratification of the Convention is now under examination by the relevant committee in the Parliament and the same situation applies in Greece. In Sweden the report of the inquiry appointed by the Government to consider the ratification is under way. Several Member States are still studying the Convention and completing their internal reforms of the legislation concerning vulnerable adults before considering ratification of the Convention. Let me name them: Romania, the United Kingdom (for England and Wales), Poland, Luxembourg, Bulgaria, Cyprus, Hungary, Malta and Denmark. We have received only a few negative replies. Croatia and the Netherlands have explicitly stated that they do not intend to ratify the Convention because, as I have already mentioned, of the budgetary costs which it may entail, and Spain has said that, from a legal point of view, accession is not deemed necessary because Spain has legally solved the international protection of adults in a balanced manner. So far Slovakia has not studied in detail whether to join the Convention. I felt I should inform you about this state of affairs in the Member States because I think it is very relevant to the discussion. As for the role of the Commission, I can solemnly declare that this is a continuing political priority, which is not only expressed in the continuing funding of the projects, but also through mainstreaming, which I will do whatever the Commission proposes regarding new legislative proposals and other activities. This is not only in the area of justice and fundamental rights, but I also intensively try to mainstream the interests of vulnerable adults in the area of transport, consumer protection policy, the energy package, the Digital Single Market strategy and, last but not least, the relatively fresh work—life balance package, where we want to enable families to better combine their duties at home, including caring for disabled, handicapped or elderly members of their families, with their work. I am very much in favour of better social services in Europe and I do not intend that care for vulnerable adults should be institutionalised or dehumanised. These are my political priorities and I would like to thank Parliament for your continued support.

name: Joëlle Bergeron
text: rapporteur. - Mr President, I would like to thank my colleagues who understood the aim of this own-initiative report, which is effectively to protect the weakest among us and to allow them to exercise their rights on the same basis as all European citizens . This sense of protection of the other can have either a philosophical or a religious origin, and it is in my opinion more important than the notion of national sovereignty. This is why, Mr. Lebreton, I believe that national sovereignty must be erased in the face of the vulnerability of the neighbor. The text of the Hague Convention - which is very good and very balanced, I have always said it - is seventeen, Mrs Jourová. It has been seventeen years that vulnerable people who have a residence abroad - which I looked after as an auctioneer - have had to wait four years, or even five, if they become heirs, to be able to inherit. They sometimes died before they could inherit. They cannot divorce, they cannot be placed in an institution, they cannot be treated since medical interventions require the agreement of a guardian, and if their measure of protection is French and they reside in Spain, they are obliged to take back a protective measure in Spain. I believe those who oppose this report have failed to understand its purpose. This report is not used to change national laws but to make life easier for the weakest. These are purely administrative measures to recognize the status of vulnerable person.

name: Preşedinte. –

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - At international level, the main existing instrument setting out the rules of international law for the protection of adults is the 2000 Convention. January 13 Hague Convention. It provides important rules for dealing with vulnerable adults, i.e. y. Cross-border problems for people aged 18 and over who are temporarily or permanently unable to take care of themselves and / or their property. However, more than 17 years after its adoption, it has been signed by 9 states and ratified by 7 states. One of the foundations of EU law is the free movement of persons. A person who is already or may be subject to protection measures in one country can move to another Member State and acquire property in several EU Member States. However, there is no single piece of legislation in the EU that allows vulnerable adults to receive adequate protection in cross-border cases. These circumstances may prevent such persons from exercising their freedom of movement and make it more difficult to protect their property. Closing this legal loophole would allow vulnerable adults to take full advantage of the EU's principles of free movement and residence and avoid potential difficulties in protecting themselves and their property. All Member States have their own legal systems with different safeguards for vulnerable adults, and the aim of this proposal is not to harmonize existing safeguards but to lay down legal rules to facilitate the recognition and enforcement of judgments given by one Member State authority and cooperation between Member States.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: signed up. - We now note that, as regards measures to protect vulnerable adults, this continues to be an area where, at European level, there continue to be discrepancies and disparities between Member States' laws on jurisdiction, applicable law, recognition and enforcement adult protection. Although there are provisions in this regard in the Hague Convention, which could address cross-border issues regarding vulnerable adults, there are Member States that have not ratified it, and this undermines the protection of vulnerable adults in cross-border situations in the Union. As such, I support the proposal to carry out and fund projects to raise awareness among European citizens about the situation of vulnerable adults and the protection measures aimed at them, as well as the services available in the field of protection of vulnerable adults.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: in writing. - Demographic change in Europe has resulted in a significant increase in the number of vulnerable adults. Currently, there are over 50 million people over 80 years of age in the world, and according to the data of the UN Committee for Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, there will be 137 million of them in 2025. Vulnerable adults include not only the elderly, but also young people with mental or physical disabilities. Each EU Member State has its own legal framework to protect vulnerable adults. Meanwhile, one of the basic EU standards is the principle of the free movement of persons, and at present there is no uniform legal framework within the Union that would adequately protect such persons in a cross-border situation. This is an obstacle to the exercise of their right to freedom of movement and hinders the protection of their property. It is therefore imperative to fill this regulatory gap. Undoubtedly, the point is not to completely harmonize the protection measures existing in individual Member States, but to implement a set of legal principles aimed at facilitating the recognition and enforcement of judgments and to develop other mechanisms that would allow the circulation and recognition of powers of attorney in all EU Member States in the event of a necessity to enter legal action.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: In written form. - In our discussions and debates, young people and the development of youth policies are a frequent focus. However, vulnerable adults who, due to impaired or insufficient personal abilities, are unable to defend their own interests, as well as those of their property, either temporarily or permanently, should not be neglected. These persons are also European citizens and also have the right to free movement and equal access to services within the Union. However, due to their different status, problems and difficulties arise. I call on the Commission to support and provide resources in order to bring EU citizens' legislation on vulnerable adults and measures to protect them to the EU's citizens. In this regard, I think it is commendable for the EU that several countries have signed the Hague Convention on the International Protection of Adults. Unfortunately, my country, Bulgaria, has not signed or ratified the convention. I call on the Bulgarian government to make the necessary conditions for the convention to be signed, ratified and incorporated into Bulgarian law, in order to ensure equal access to services and opportunities for all citizens.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D)
text: signed up. - It is already known that the protection of vulnerable adults, whether the vulnerability is of physical or psychological origin, exercising their freedom of movement within the EU, is a cross-border issue related to fundamental human rights. Protecting the vulnerable is an EU mission and is needed in the context of discrepancies between Member States' laws on jurisdiction, applicable law and the enforcement of measures to protect vulnerable adults. The diversity of applicable law and the multiplicity of competent courts can affect not only the right of vulnerable adults to move and reside freely in an EU Member State, but also the protection of their heritage. The recommendation to the Commission that the protection measures taken by the authorities of one Member State be automatically recognized in the other Member States is therefore welcome. Thus, people who are vulnerable due to age-related illnesses or disabilities, who live in other European countries or who move within the Union can benefit from more rights and more protection. Clearly, the implementation of the recommendations in this report requires the application of cooperation mechanisms between Member States, in order to facilitate and promote communication between competent authorities.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I strongly support the report with recommendations to the Commission on the protection of vulnerable adult groups. The protection of vulnerable groups is about the protection of basic human rights and the enjoyment of basic human rights must not and cannot end at the borders of the members of the European Union. That is why I join the calls on the European Commission for Member States to set up central bodies to exchange the necessary information between EU Member States on the rights and situation of vulnerable people. This will be for vulnerable people and their guardians or. certainly provide the Commissioners with a more dignified and less complex life in their movement and residence within the European Union. It is our duty and the duty of the European Commission to call on the Member States of the European Union that have not yet ratified the Hague Convention to do so as soon as possible. Protection of vulnerable groups at the international level or. level of international law is all the more important in the light of demographic change. The European Union and its members must therefore play an advanced and visible role in adopting international instruments for the protection of vulnerable groups. Demographic change in Europe is changing our society, and it is more than necessary for international law to adapt to this. The population of the European Union is getting older, and we will therefore have to pay even more attention to protecting the rights of the elderly and all vulnerable groups in the future.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR).
text: – Madam President, it is a little late, but I just wanted to say that today is the official global day of parents. text: – Madam President, I would like to ask for the referral back to the Committee for Interinstitutional Negotiations.

text: This concludes Voting Time.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: - I voted in favor of this report because it rationally identifies the benefits of advancing the digital world. We talk about education, health, industry. All true, but we cannot look to the future without considering the reality of the present. A 5G Europe today looks almost like a science fiction movie. In Europe, the digital divide that exists between regions, particularly between rural and urban areas, is still considerable. We must start from the awareness that rural areas, as well as mountainous or island areas, are unlikely to enjoy the same benefits deriving from the gigabit society that are felt in cities or central regions. Just think of broadband, which is not yet a homogeneous reality throughout Europe. The danger is that 5G increases this gap between regions by marginalizing the peripheral ones and the weaker ones. So why not start investing in these less developed regions? The proposal is provocative, of course, but perhaps it could be the right stimulus for necessary progress towards a 5G society that cannot leave anyone behind.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Madam President, the telecommunications revolution has improved people’s lives in a way that no legislation from this or any other chamber can begin to approach. There has been an absolute transformation of the human condition, particularly in developing countries, and it is something almost wholly unforeseen by politicians. What’s been the response of the European Commission? I can’t help noticing that there have been an awful lot of legal actions in the last five years against US-based tech firms, perhaps in pursuit of what Commissioner Oettinger calls ‘digital independence’ for the EU. Microsoft, Google, Apple – they’ve all been on the receiving end of it. Of course there aren’t really European equivalents to these firms, and perhaps the reason for that is because of the regulatory regime that we’ve created here. It may be no coincidence that since the Brexit vote we’ve seen Google and Apple, and most recently Snapchat, relocating to London in full knowledge that Britain is leaving the European Union. Perhaps it’s precisely because of what they know about the EU’s regulatory environment that they’re shifting.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, I voted in favour of this excellent and innovative report. The 5G network presents our societies and the European Union’s industry with new and great digital possibilities by enabling new connectivity opportunities via both high-quality and high-capacity networks. In addition, I fully agree with the idea expressed in the report that in order to seize these opportunities we need to ensure that the necessary conditions to develop 5G infrastructure are in place by 2020-25 and, I hope, much earlier, namely: a transparent, competitive and investment-friendly regulatory framework, and a willingness from EU Member States to create a much-needed common network of operability at the EU level.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: - Madam President, I strongly support the European Commission's ambitious plan to provide ultra-fast internet in primary and secondary schools, universities and libraries from 2025. I believe that this will improve the way students learn the teaching material, as well as the teaching methods. However, I find the huge difference between the countries in the European Union in terms of access to high-speed internet worrying. The situation is even worse in rural and remote areas, where there is no 3G and 4G. This further deepens the gap between town and country. Unfortunately, Bulgaria is again at the bottom of the ranking for the entry of digital technologies. Only 55% of Bulgarian households are subscribed for a fixed broadband connection. Against the background of these statistics, it seems absurd that Mr. Borissov's priority is the creation of e-government, while at the same time only 31% of Bulgarians have basic digital skills.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE).
text: - 100MB / s is a minimum for all consumers.1 to 100GB / s for large financial companies, industry, means of transport, transport institutions is actually the norm at the moment.However, I would like to point out one thing: by accelerating the development of all qualitative elements of the digital market, on the other hand, we are leading to a very serious situation of a competence gap in the digital field, i.e. certain digital exclusions.On this occasion, I would like to emphasize the necessity of educational tasks, especially in schools, in order to limit these exclusions in the digital market.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I was in favour because 5G will be the next key building block of our future society. The Commission’s action plan, aimed at making the EU a world leader in the deployment of standardised 5G networks from 2020-25, is rather ambitious. Our task is to ensure that this ambitious plan will be fulfilled. To reach that aim the Commission, the Member States and the European Parliament should coherently fulfil their parts of the common task. The Commission should ensure long-term financing for the 5G action plan and network modernisation; Member States should implement the 5G action plan in regions and cities, and implement measures for a high common level of security of network and information systems across the Union. We should step up efforts on standardisation and adopt effective measures to fight piracy. The direction is right, ambitions are high, so we should go forward and not repeat previous mistakes.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I also voted in favor because I consider access to the Internet to be an absolutely key agenda in all the European Union's practical policies, and I would like to point out that access to the Internet has not only improved quality of life but is actually a condition for electronic public care.news.And this has already been said here by my colleague Nekov, and I consider it very important that the scissors between the countryside and the central areas do not open further.It is assumed that 70% of the European population will live in the largest European agglomerations within twenty years, and if you say somewhere in the countryside today that they may not even have access to 3G, then if we talk about access to 5G operating speed today, we are actually having fun.as if on a trip to Mars.It is important that these scissors do not open further and that we focus on keeping people in the countryside.Internet access is very crucial for this.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I also supported this report. I consider it very important for the European Union to address the issue of high-speed internet access. After all, the topic of digitalisation of society is one of the key topics of the European Union and it is also a key topic of this period of the European Parliament. After all, I also supported another report on the digitization of society, and that is the digitization of European industry, which we also voted on today. Colleagues have already explained here today, and even during the debate, it was explained why this topic is important. If we want to keep the European Union, European countries and leaders in world technology and world industry, then we cannot do without a digital revolution. That is why I support all these proposals, the European Commission will need to address the level of investment in these technologies, because in Europe we invest only a third compared to the United States in modern digital technologies. More money is needed, not just to talk about it in general.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I have always advocated strongly for initiatives that support the growth and spread of high-speed connectivity throughout all of Europe. In recent years I’ve observed its true potential being realised by Irish and European citizens alike. The implementation of faster and higher-quality connectivity for all Europeans can act as a vital vehicle of improvement in the areas of economic growth and employment for all areas of European society. This report will pay a key role in the advancement of Europe’s Digital Agenda and will allow us to maintain our position at the forefront of global innovation and investment by becoming a 5G and gigabit society.
