name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Madam President, there is one charge against which I would always defend members of this House, and that is the widespread belief in many of our Member States that MEPs are lazy: that we come here and sit around and do nothing. Frankly, the world would be a much better place if that charge were true: if, instead of constantly legislating, people would come in, and clock in for their very generous attendance allowance, and then go and work on their golf handicap or read a novel, or do something other than meddling in the lives of everybody else. But, of course, human nature being what it is, we – having claimed all of these generous expenses – decide we have to do something, we have to justify our work in some way, and so we produce reports like this.  On what conceivable measure is this anything that has to do with the European Union? Of course the protection of vulnerable adults is a critical function but by any conceivable … (heckling) I am sorry but I am being heckled by a sort of lefty Yahoo over there, who is gibbering and ranting like a stricken animal. But, by any conceivable supposition, this is something that is reserved for the Member States. Why not recognise the limits of what we can do?

name: Reinhard Bütikofer (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to ask you to censor this so-called colleague who is insulting the whole House.

name: La Présidente. –
text: Mr Bütikofer, I am not empowered to sanction Mr Hannan.On the other hand, if you make a comment in writing, we will take it into account and we will examine it, of course.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Madam President, I voted in favor of the report. As I said in my speech a while ago, vulnerable adults need protection, especially those adults, especially the elderly, who suffer from mental illnesses such as Alzheimer's or physical illnesses and disabilities, especially at a time when the population of its citizens European Union over the age of 60 reaches 37%, while 10% of the European Union population is over the age of 80. Cooperation between Member States on adult legal aid, such as the recognition of judicial decisions in this area, is essential and the report we have voted on facilitates this cooperation, as well as the protection of vulnerable adults moving across borders within the European Union. .

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I supported this report. Unlike one of the speakers, I think that at a time when the number of seniors is growing, who unfortunately suffer from certain health problems at a late stage and are therefore partially inadequate, it is necessary to address the issue of how to protect these people. In the Czech Republic, for example, we have adopted a new Civil Code, which very significantly protects persons who are limited in their autonomy, and it is clear that if these persons enter into cross-border legal relations, it is necessary for the European Union to address this issue and has provided protection to such people as the population ages, and as I have already indicated, all experts agree that, unfortunately, in the older generation, there is a growing number of different nervous diseases in older seniors, which can lead to reduced self-sufficiency. These people need to be given a dignified life and their rights protected. This report talks about that, which is why I support it, because I think it is logical and can help people who find themselves in a difficult situation.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Ukraine is a neighbor and partner of the European Union. I believe that we must work and cooperate with her. For me, however, the priority should be the interests and concerns of European and, in particular, Bulgarian producers. I did not support the proposal to increase the duty-free import of several agricultural industrial products, because the producers in my country Bulgaria are already feeling pressure from the already existing duty-free regime. Last year, thousands of tons of honey remained unsold in Bulgaria due to imports from third countries. Oilseed growers are also feeling pressure from imports from Ukraine. In the world, neoliberalism and free trade are suffocating the European producer. It faces a number of legal requirements, environmental standards and a number of other challenges. With facilitated imports, we add additional competition to this set of difficulties. Let us make the single market accessible and working for the European producer.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, I did indeed vote in favour of this report on the Commission’s proposal suggesting additional temporary economic trade preferences for Ukraine. We need to understand that Ukraine is at the moment undergoing enormous economic difficulties and at the same time undertaking very complex economic reforms. Therefore, I believe that this Commission proposal is both timely and right. It is complementary to the already existing EU concessions and the DCFTA trade preferences, and will allow increasing annual tariff rate quotas for certain products. I believe it will help to speed up Ukraine’s economic recovery, deal with the consequences of the ongoing embargo from the Russian side and further facilitate bilateral trade relations between Ukraine and the European Union.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: - Madam President, Ukraine's gross domestic product increased by more than 1% in 2016. By voting for this report, Ukraine will receive another impetus for development. But we need to make sure that this money, made from duty-free trade in the European Union, only reaches people and not the pockets of oligarchs. Practically, according to this agreement, for three years Ukraine will export to European markets, without customs duties, cereals, fruits, industrial products. We must take measures to prevent an increased flow of cheap grain from Ukraine to the Union market at the same time. And last but not least, the Ukrainian authorities must step up the fight against corruption and anti-fraud, set up anti-corruption courts more quickly and depoliticize the judiciary, appoint a non-political prosecutor, such as today, and one who will have legal education and legal experience.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I supported this report on the proposal for a regulation introducing temporary autonomous trade measures for Ukraine, which should allow higher exports of agricultural and industrial products from Ukraine to the Union.At the same time, these measures should not have any significant impact on the European market.However, they can fundamentally help Ukraine.I would like to remind you that in 2015, Ukrainian GDP fell by 9.8% and the share of Ukrainian trade with Russia also fell from 27% to 13%.In 2014, the Ukrainians chose to integrate with the democratic European Union over the sphere of influence of Putin's Russia and paid heavily for this choice.In conclusion, I would like to express my great pleasure that the ratification of the Association Agreement with Ukraine has been completed in the Netherlands, so there is nothing to prevent its effectiveness.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE).
text: - An instrument in the form of economic measures for Ukraine is a good idea, therefore I supported it.But I want to highlight two important elements: first, the appearance of this instrument is a response to the situation in Ukraine, which, in short, is bad, both in terms of the condition of the economy and, more importantly, in terms of reforms.For those reforms that were to improve the economic situation, financial situation and the functioning of economic entities.However, with this vote, I would like to call for this instrument to be addressed primarily to small and medium-sized economic entities and not to the most important large oligarchic entities, because this will not improve the situation in Ukraine.And on this occasion, it is also worth noting the need to build certain mechanisms supporting civil society and small economic entities, for example in Belarus.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Madam President, I voted against the report on the introduction of autonomous trade measures for Ukraine because it provides for additional trade concessions for the duty-free import from Ukraine of cereals, processed tomatoes, honey and grape juice. With these regulations, as well as with the European Union-Ukraine Free Trade Area, we have aggregate and duty-free import of agricultural products and food from Ukraine, as a result of which the economy of European Union countries, such as Greece, is damaged and interests are dissolved. of Greek farmers, stockbreeders, beekeepers, and the Greek food industries. As I have argued at other times, there is a need to reinstate the principle of Community preference, a principle on which the EEC, which provided protection for Community farmers, was based. The European Union, in the name of political support for Ukraine, cannot dismantle the agricultural economies of its Member States, especially Greece. So I voted against the report.

name: Charles Tannock (ECR).
text: – Madam President, as Russia continues the proxy war in the east of Ukraine and its illegal occupation of Crimea, it is right in this House that we and in the rest of the European Union continue to support Ukraine, standing up for the rules-based international order and values that we all believe in, and also demand a full implementation of the Minsk agreements. Ukraine has seen its share of exports to Russia halve since 2013, a major dislocation of its trade given the historic links between the two countries. So I strongly welcome the DCFTA that has been in place since last year, and I’m equally supportive of these additional measures that aim to further support Ukraine’s now-growing economy and its further integration into the European Union’s Single Market. We do now see a commitment by Ukraine to transition to a full market economy. I’m also pleased that the Netherlands ratified the association agreement this week, a welcome sign showing that the EU is now fully united in support of Ukraine and its Euro-Atlantic aspirations.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Madam President, as written in the annotation, the aim of this legislative proposal is to increase the existing trade flows and to foster bilateral trade and economic cooperation between Ukraine and the EU. But in the same document it is written that the European Union will see a loss of customs revenue corresponding to less than EUR 50 million annually with a very limited impact on the EU’s own resources. Limited impact means that, in reality, this proposal is empty. It is the lowest possible result. Nevertheless, the Committee on International Trade (INTA), based on trade suggested, made additional cuts for certain product groups, such as wheat, maize and processed tomatoes. We can compare it with a situation where someone presents a gift to his friends in a very big, beautiful box, but inside there is a very small piece of candy at the bottom. Such a gift can be perceived only as mockery.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I supported this report and I would like to begin by saying that, in my opinion, the support that should go towards the Ukrainian economy should be higher. However, if at least this measure was on the table, I was happy to support it. I think that, to a certain extent, we must have a bad conscience about how violations of international law in Russia could actually have gone with impunity. And if the European Union could not help militarily in any way, this is of course not our goal, and it was not even possible, then the only support may be to support the Ukrainian economy and maintain the embargo that European countries have imposed. However, we must not forget the regions that will be affected by these measures, within the European Union. These are mainly the surrounding regions, and we should also take some supportive steps towards them. I would also clearly like to appreciate the completion of the ratification of the Association Agreement with Ukraine, because this step by the Netherlands is undoubtedly very pro-European in the light of the referendum that has taken place.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I also supported this report, but like some colleagues, I am a little disappointed that the project is not very ambitious and that, on the contrary, the range of products that should be in the duty-free zone has narrowed within the European Parliament. duty free zone, that is, our assistance to Ukraine is here, but it is much smaller than originally proposed by the European Commission, and I personally believe that this is, as one of the speakers said, a small gift in a big box with a big ribbon. So yes, support yes, but in the future we should think about how to help Ukraine more. It is in our geopolitical interest, in Europe's interest, for Ukraine to survive, to stabilize itself and for pro-Russian forces not to grow there in the future. It is our own interest, that is, letting Ukraine into the European market is not only our generosity, we are doing it not only because we want a democratic and stable Ukraine, but we are doing it in our own interest. That is how we should approach it and therefore be perhaps more generous than this proposal.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, tá mórán fulaingthe ag muintir na hÚcráine, ar dtús nuair a bhí siad faoi smacht díreach na Rúise agus le déanaí agus an Rúis ag tógaint an Chrimé uatha agus ag iarraidh tionchar mífhéaráilte a bheith acu orthu. Ach dúirt muintir na hÚcráine ó 2013 i leith gur fearr leo féachaint siar ná soir agus dá bhrí sin is dóigh liom gur cinneadh maith é sin dóibh agus dúinne, agus tá sé ceart agus cóir go dtabharfaimid aitheantas ar an gcinneadh sin trí chabhrú leo chun a ngeilleagar a fhás, chun jabanna a chruthú agus chun a dtáirgí a dhíol. Agus dá bhrí sin, is dóigh liom gur maith an tuarascáil í chun seans a thabhairt dóibh easpórtáil isteach san Aontas agus is dóigh liom freisin go bhfuil moladh tuillte ag Uachtaránacht Mhálta as ucht teacht ar chomhréiteach faoi na moltaí is deacra a bhí sa tuarascáil seo, go háirithe mar a bhain le cúrsaí talamhaíochta. Tá súil agam go bhfuil saol maith roimh an Úcráin amach anseo agus go mbeidh siad mar bhall den Aontas lá éigin.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Madam President, I am referring first to my speech on this issue, which I made a moment ago during the debate here in the European Parliament. I voted against the report. I believe that Greece, in order to stop being a magnet for refugees and especially thousands of illegal immigrants, must leave Schengen. At the same time, border control by the Member States themselves and the reintroduction of national border controls ensure the security and surveillance of incoming persons. In addition, the bilingualism of the European Union, which has abolished visas for Kosovo, where the jihadist sphinx is located, must stop. Thus, after the European Union opened its door to the free movement of jihadists through Kosovo, now with this legislative initiative it is trying to close the window to the illegal entry into the European Union of persons who forge visas. And all this when thousands of illegal immigrants are flooding the European Union.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: - Madam President, we need more judicial cooperation in criminal matters, between the police forces, but also European agencies, such as the European Agency for Human Rights.Talking with the Director of the Agency, I found improvements in this agency in terms of transparency, the introduction of conflicts of interest and the desire and the beginning of the expansion of activity and competence and in matters of the rule of law: to be involved in the rule of law in all states.member.Also get involved in what happens in human rights refugee camps, along with the police, for example, who deal with the criminal side and punish those who break the laws of the country where they are.I wish them success and hopefully they will produce much more than inefficient studies.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI).
text: - Madam President, we had better sweep outside our door. Europe, especially through this agency, is trying, for example, to protect the rights of migrants, to make people feel guilty - it must be said - what we should call today, I believe, the native population, and even rejects any legitimate difference relating to nationality when it is quite legitimate that, for example, the French have priority in their country as foreigners are in theirs. This Europe is incapable of protecting fundamental rights. We have not been able to protect the two most iconic political refugees who have exposed us to American espionage, MM. Julian Assange and Edward Snowden. Mr. Edward Snowden, to the shame of the European Union and all member countries, ultimately found refuge only in Moscow. Mr. Julian Assange had to live in literally prison conditions in a South American embassy because he was being prosecuted under a particularly grotesque charge by Swedish plaintiffs. I think this brings the agency and our fundamental rights discourse into disrepute.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Madam President, I could not support this recommendation in the vote because I believe that in this form it does not meet the current needs of European citizens and countries.When it comes to fundamental rights, the focus is again on migrants, refugees and certain minority groups, instead of all Union citizens and those who have come to Europe by law to escape danger, to go to school and to work.Millions of Europeans today are socially excluded, marginalized by the processes of economic globalization and living neglected in environments that have not yet overcome the crisis.While this is the case, I do not see why we should focus exclusively on minority groups and immigrants, thus further widening the gap between them and the domicile population.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI).
text: - Madam President, this procedural artifice allows me to double my speaking time.I therefore continue by saying, as Ms. Tomašić has excellently suggested, that the real victims of this kind of policy are the original occupiers.I am personally, perhaps to my misfortune, European.I'm a family man, so I'm heterosexual.I am more of a French patriot.I can see that I am the object of all this logorrhea which keeps trying to make me feel guilty, to impose on me an unwanted foreign presence, which wants to demonize any legitimate attempt at national reaction.This is the reason why I consider all of these operations and this discourse to be a real enterprise of decerebration, of guilt, a psychological weapon in the hands of globalism and against the European populations.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: - Madam President, a digital industry means strengthening the economy, better social cohesion.When industries are connected, investment increases, jobs increase, resources are capitalized more efficiently, raw materials are protected and used responsibly.At the same time, a digital industry is driving and giving a huge boost to innovation.Without innovation we cannot progress in a world that changes every day.We can produce and create high standards in our countries.There are legislative measures that can bring great benefits to Romania as well, everything depends on the political will, as in every country.We have the right financial instruments, the European Fund for Strategic Investments, Horizon 2020 and I mean regional funds.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I supported the report on the digitalisation of European industry because I believe that the development of the digital industry has the potential to contribute to tackling Europe's fundamental social and economic problems.These include, but are not limited to, social inequalities and youth unemployment.40% of European workers still lack the necessary digital skills and there is a risk that this potential will simply remain untapped.We must therefore support digital literacy for all sections of the population, including the elderly and minorities.I therefore also call on the Member States to provide their citizens with appropriate assistance in their schools as part of retraining courses, inter alia with the help of European Social Fund funding.

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I will start with something that I find extremely dramatic. The percentage of adults in Europe who do not currently have the most basic, most basic skill: the ability to use a computer mouse is in double digits. At the same time, we aim to have 20% of our GDP based on industry by 2020. If we take into account the structural transformation of the industry and the emergence of new business models, then we easily conclude that we may have a million jobs that will be vacant due to digital illiteracy, while we can create 10% GDP growth only from tourism and through digitization. At a time when we can benefit consumers through digitization, by comparing the provision of services. It is necessary, in the era of 5G, to cover the digital divide. It is necessary for the regions and the municipalities to provide the small and medium enterprises with the digital possibility, so that they can very quickly pass to the new era.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: - Madam President, I supported Mr Boutikofer's report because I believe that the European Union needs an integrated industrial digitization strategy more than ever. We must not overlook the fact that it will have a direct impact on both the educational and the social spheres. Speaking of education, I think it is appropriate to point out that within the European Union, 40 percent of workers do not have digital skills. It is imperative that the acquisition of digital skills be embedded in national curricula. In addition, we must note that there is a shortage of around 180,000 IT professionals in Europe every year, while at the same time hundreds of young people are out of work and have no prospects for development. The social dimension of the digitalisation of industry must also not be overlooked. New technologies bring new opportunities for citizens, but at the same time they imply job losses and, consequently, social security. The European Union must, above all, be socially responsible and provide protection for all if it does not want to lose the trust of its citizens.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I supported this report together, if I took a good note, with five hundred and seventy-one of my colleagues.In my opinion, this report is not political at all and shows that our economy simply will not survive in the future without consistent digitization.This is the same as Mr Boni's report on access to 5G.An economy without consistent digitization would not perform as well as it is today.It is necessary to digitize precisely for better investment, for achieving more jobs, for generally more resource-efficient management and for attracting innovation.All of this is important, and it is a precondition for the economy - both industry and services - to grow and be competitive in the global market.It simply won't work without digitization.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE).
text: - This report had a rather unfortunate side effect, not to say unfortunate.It turned out that 40% of European society does not have the so-calleddigital competences.My friend Šojdrová spoke about educational needs, and I can subscribe to it.But on this occasion I want to point out the misinterpretation of these digital competences.It is not about simply clicking or being able to turn on a computer, but about the ability to use the Internet, the network, this digital resource for work.It is necessary to distinguish the competency element, which is related to entertainment, using the entire digital resource simply for pleasure, and the one which is a tool of the profession or work performed.I draw your attention to this because there are numerous misunderstandings on this occasion.

name: Stefano Maullu (PPE).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that this report highlights the focal point of Europe's development for the coming decades.The digitalization of industries is the goal we must aim for, especially in an increasingly competitive market that sees competition for large global areas of the world.So, going in this direction, from 5G to everything that makes our industry, our production system more efficient, more competitive and more innovative, means guaranteeing our Europe even more a position of dominance in the universe and in the world.So I believe that from this point of view the vote in favor of the report goes to guarantee what we share, that is, a united Europe, a cohesive Europe, a Europe that increasingly guarantees the world competitiveness.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I voted in favour of this proposal which calls for the boosting of Europe’s digital innovation capacities through partnerships in digital technologies, value chains, digital innovation hubs in all regions and prioritising standards. This is absolutely vital if we are to become more competitive in Europe and at the international level, and greater digitisation of industries throughout Europe, including in my own country, Ireland, is a priority. One area I just want to mention is the area of shortage of skills. There’s an organisation in Ireland called Coderdojo which helps young people to develop the skills necessary. I hope that all countries in Europe could found Coderdojo clubs and I am looking for MEPs to become an ambassador in their own country for this, because this is needed to get the coding skills that are necessary to fill the jobs that are lying vacant at the moment, and the many thousands of jobs that will be created into the future. So, MEPs: Coderdojo, become an ambassador.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I voted in favor of this resolution in recognition that the European Union must take a leading position in implementing the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. Adopted by the UN in September 2015, it provides an ambitious framework for achieving sustainable development and eradicating poverty. This decision weighed in on the fact that today we live in a time of growing uncertainty and ambiguity, which opens a question about the future of some consensus already reached around energy and climate objectives, which aims at a green, sustainable economy, giving priority to the fight against climate change. The world has changed since the last European consensus on development, adopted in 2005. Today, we are faced with demographic changes worldwide, associated with economic, social and environmental changes, and the levels of poverty and inequality, as well as their distribution. geographic, have changed. This new consensus seeks to find lasting solutions to complex global challenges and the European Union and the Member States must commit themselves firmly to the implementation of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, promoting the universal values ​​of democracy, good governance, the rule of law and human rights for all.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI).
text: - Madam President, I voted against this report. For a long time, development policy was mainly about taking money from the poor in rich countries and giving it to the rich in poor countries. It is true that the current report has much better sentiments, but it flies in two ways. The first is that the only original idea it contains is above all not to link the granting of development to the control required of the recipient countries of their migratory flows. In my opinion, this is a mistake. We could very well ask these countries to cooperate insofar as, precisely, development aid aims to try to prevent their nationals from being tempted to flee the misery they encounter in their country of origin. . The second aspect that is overlooked is that there will be no development if there is no protectionism. It is protectionism which allows economies to take off, which allows the protection of subsistence agriculture and which also makes it possible to move from the artisanal stage to the industrial stage. The history of all developed countries, including China and Japan, which have consistently sought the repeal of unequal treaties, demonstrates this.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Madam President, the challenges that twenty years ago faced in developing countries today, after many years of prosperity, have become relevant in our European countries.Poverty, insecurity and social exclusion are commonplace for millions of Europeans.I will always support the constructive role of the European Union in the poor parts of the world and all positive efforts to get them back on their feet, without imperialist aspirations and exploitative intentions, so that we can trade and prosper together on an equal footing.However, I am of the opinion that the Union's role in the world must not overshadow the role it must play at home.The EU must encourage Member States to make business and employment easier so that everyone can find work and invest in infrastructure so that all parts of Europe are well connected and live in conditions worthy of the 21st century.

name: Diane James (NI).
text: – Madam President, the European Union’s global strategy aims to be both principled and pragmatic, yet this is clearly impossible. The policy can only be either principled, or pragmatic, it cannot be both. And here the European Union is trying to use words to pull the wool over our eyes. It is making the claim that it can be all things to all men in the name of promoting civil society. The reality is that the European Union is consolidating its strengths as a global actor to compensate for, and in the wake of, Brexit. It is hardening its tone internationally, often in areas that do not concern it, and is accelerating its plans for its own military forces. But the sad reality of European Union foreign policy is that it has a history of destabilising regions like the Ukraine and the Balkans, and also unleashing events that it cannot control, like the migrant crisis. It did not have my support today.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Madam President, resilience is a very important factor to make the external actions of the EU effective. There are a lot of challenges along this way, among them I would like to stress two factors: bureaucracy and political blindness. Bureaucracy makes our external actions slow, inflexible and rigid. Political blindness we can see very often here, even in this House. A lot of politicians live in a virtual world of their illusions, emotions, local interests and ideologies – they do not want to see the cultural and historical background of concrete countries. They put in place red lines, limitations and labels – very easy. But sometimes, after they have lost interest, these restrictions remain. This makes the job of the professionals that work with fragile states on the ground very difficult, and narrows the number of possibilities and instruments of the EU’s External Action Service. So we should not only give recommendations to others, but also start with a critical view of our own political participation.

name: Diane James (NI).
text: – Madam President, whilst it was recently reported that the rise in anti-Semitism in the UK was one of the highest in the world, much of it is due to increased anti-Semitic abuse online, particularly via social media. Now that is unacceptable, but I am just trying to make a point in terms of where that is coming from. Challenging anti-Semitism in the United Kingdom is always going to be a problem while we have one mainstream political party seen by the media, seen in terms of public opinion – and I am referring to the Labour Party – failing consistently to deal with the problem within its own ranks, very often trying to disguise its deep-rooted prejudices as anti-Zionist or anti-Israeli. The party in my opinion – and this is my view, I can only go with what I hear and see – has seemingly time and time again refused to tackle the issue within its own senior ranks, just inflicting simple reprimands but actually not dealing with the issue. If anti-Semitism is going to be dealt with, and the UK is a good example, then political parties need to take responsibility.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I would like to say that the Holocaust is part of the common European memory. The anti-Semitic attacks, which are growing significantly in the new millennium - and we can mention Toulouse, Brussels, Paris - are in direct conflict with the ideals of European integration. Whether their perpetrators are extreme right-wing radicals or Islamists. It is therefore good that the European Commission, as well as national governments, is coming up with more initiatives against anti-Semitism. That is also why I supported and am pleased that the amendment was approved for the European Union and the Member States to adopt the definition of anti-Semitism used by the International Community for Holocaust Remembrance. This definition is necessary in identifying and punishing anti-Semitic manifestations, which are growing significantly on social networks. This is a phenomenon that we must fight vigorously. The Audiovisual Media Services Directive will also provide us with some tools, which we will be able to use.

name: Jan Zahradil (ECR).
text: - Madam President, anti-Semitism is on the rise in Europe. That is a fact, that is a fact that needs to be addressed, and it is worrying, and I am afraid that this phenomenon will not just disappear, because it is a different type of anti-Semitism than we have known in the past, for example in the 1930s in Germany. The new anti-Semitism is linked to structural and demographic changes in societies in some European countries, creating strong diasporas from countries with a confrontational or downright hostile relationship with the State of Israel, and recruiting Islamist radicals who are the bearers of this new anti-Semitism . This must be acknowledged, not a blind eye in the name of false political correctness, and the European Union must also take this into account, for example, when providing development and humanitarian and other financial assistance to certain countries in the Middle East and North Africa.

name: Pascal Durand (Verts/ALE).
text: - Madam President, we have just adopted a resolution which rightly denounces anti-Semitism around the world. The difficulty is that in this resolution, and for the first time, a possible connection can be made between anti-Semitism and criticism of the colonial policies implemented by the Israeli government. There is a real danger here because, quite simply, criticism of colonial policies and the occupation has nothing to do with anti-Semitism. It is a matter of human dignity, of the Palestinian people who are deprived of their rights, their land and basic rights to water or education. To make the connection between criticism of the Israeli government's colonial and military practices and the suffering suffered as a result of anti-Semitism is to insult all those who try to defend a peaceful and dignified solution in the Middle East so that the State of Palestine can live in peace alongside a peaceful State of Israel.

name: Илхан Кючюк (ALDE).
text: - Madam President, I voted in favor of this proposed resolution because it sends a strong signal to the democratic community around the world and it is that no one deserves to be abused and discriminated against on the basis of ethnicity and religion, skin color or sexual orientation. People of Jewish origin are the most suffering in the recent history of Europe and as a citizen of the Republic of Bulgaria I am truly proud that my country managed to save the Jewish community in the country during the Second World War. Unfortunately, 72 years later, events are taking place in Bulgaria that are an attack on the memory of Holocaust victims. A few weeks ago, the new Bulgarian government appointed a deputy minister, who was accused of taking a photo showing a Nazi salute. Here is the photo. Here is another one. Then the Deputy Prime Minister of NATO and European Bulgaria - Valeri Simeonov, replied that in the 70s of the last century he had been taken to the Buchenwald camp and said, quoting: "When you think about it, who knows what prank photos I took. "It simply came to our notice then. I ring the bell and call on Europe to show zero tolerance for a government that mocks the memory of the victims.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE).
text: - Her name was Sarah, she was 65, she was a daycare director and a Jew. Sarah died on April 4, in Belleville, beaten to death and defenestrated by a young radicalized Muslim. No national march, no Une pour Sarah. She died in near media indifference and, worse, in the freezing silence of the authorities. The murderer is a neighbor. He knew his victim. He called her a dirty Jew on a daily basis, terrorized her, but the courts are now in the dark and "question" the anti-Semitic nature of this crime. We believe we are dreaming, as we hallucinate, when we hear some, just now in this hemicycle, who question and for the same reasons, no doubt, the international definition of anti-Semitism. An essential definition. Should we still summon Camus here if we want to name things, act and continue accordingly. We owe it to Emmanuel and Miriam Riva to name things, to Dominique Sabrier and Alexandre Strens from the Jewish Museum in Brussels, to Jonathan Sandler, to Arié and Gabriel, to little Myriam from the Ozar-Hatorah college in Toulouse, to Yoav Hattab, Yohan Cohen, François-Michel Saada and Philippe Braham from the hyper-hide, and to all the others. We owe it to Sarah Halimi.

name: Charles Tannock (ECR).
text: – Madam President, whilst I welcome today’s resolution, it is tragic that 70 years on from the Nazi atrocities such a resolution is even necessary. It is quite clear from the statistics that the number of anti-Semitic attacks, both verbal and physical, is on the rise in Europe, including in my own country, the United Kingdom, particularly on the internet. Indeed, we saw in Paris and in Brussels in the last few years actual terrorist attacks specifically committed against a kosher supermarket and the Jewish Museum in Brussels. As the populations of EU Member States become ever more diverse it is important we pay close attention to encouraging and ensuring that the successful social cohesion and integration of all communities is worked towards. I am pleased, therefore, that the resolution goes beyond looking just at the topic at hand, but at the need to ease tensions across all the divides. I particularly welcome the emphasis on cross-border cooperation with regard to this issue, and the need to work together in times of terrorist attacks, particularly in the realm of sharing intelligence on extremist groups. Finding ways to prevent the radicalisation of vulnerable individuals will also be key in this area.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I am the last speaker in this debate and I have to say that there is really little to be said that other colleagues have not said. It is deplorable, at this time in the 21st century European Union, that many of our citizens live in fear of discrimination, abuse and hate crimes simply because of their religion. As Vice—President responsible for Parliament’s dialogue with religions, I have been meeting religious leaders from across the European Union including, of course, Jewish leaders. We are hearing stories that send shivers down our spine of children being afraid to go to school and families contemplating leaving Europe because of the fears that they have. I was therefore happy this week to contribute to the launch of the OSCE’s practical guide to combating anti-Semitism. This work should help public authorities to take the necessary steps to ensure the safety and security of our religious communities. This is absolutely vital and I fully support this resolution.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI).
text: - Please excuse me but, unless I am mistaken, I was also listed on this report.Can the session service check?

name: La Présidente. –
text: Sorry sir, no, you weren't registered.We don't have your name, so we'll move on to the explanation of vote on the sequel.I'm sorry sir.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, the time has come to take action to protect our oceans. We agree, the trouble is that this statement is made in the middle of a toast to the sun and just a few days before the global celebration of Oceans Day. We need to develop networks of marine protected areas, reduce waste and develop effective measures for adaptation and mitigation of climate change, both in the oceans and in coastal ecosystems. This requires a strong political will, stopping the feet of the corporations that continue to monopolize our seas and commercialize our resources. In this sense, we are particularly concerned about the situation of the tellurium mine deposit in the Canary Islands. I would like neither this Commission nor this Parliament, when the time comes, to skimp on the inquiries that have to be made to find out what they want to do, what the Government of the Popular Party in Spain wants to do with this deposit, because it does not give any kind of information. What you have to do, if you want to protect the sea, is precisely to close the door to those who destroy our oceans and the life of the planet, because the sea is a legacy and it is a treasure and it must be protected.

name: La Présidente. –
text: This concludes the explanations of vote.

name: La Présidente. –
text: I declare the session of the European Parliament adjourned.(The meeting rose at 12.50 p.m.)
